Home to lots of high class shops now its still worth window shopping if you enjoy looking at one of Sydney's historical buildings. Lots of places to sit down and have a coffee or light meal. One of my favourite shops Haighs Chocolates is in this building. I always wander through when visiting Sydney.
Beautiful building . Loved looking at the windows ceilings colours clocks in this beautiful well maintained building. A lovely shopping experience. Be sure to check out dr sues art gallery!!

Shopping, coffee and a chat. QVB has four floors and every floor is fill of designer as well as stylish budget shops. If you're a tourist interested in architecture, the inside of QVB will interest you. A nineteenth century building designed by George McRae, it was built in recession times and dedicated to the then Empress Queen Victoria. Originally it was made to become a concert hall, hold coffee shops and tradespeople. Today, the concert hall is the city library. The building is right in the middle of the city, located between York Street and George Street. It is a fine place to meet friends and share a cup of coffee in one of the various coffee shops located inside.

Shopping experience with a difference. This is not your everyday shopping complex but a beautifully restored building that houses speciality shops, designer shops, cafes and eateries. The architectural detail in the masonry and tiling is lovingly presented. You can tell a lot of planning went into bringing history back to life. I spent two hours one afternoon taking in the ambience of the building. It is especially attractive during a bright day with the glass ceilings letting in natural light.
Amazing... I would personally recommend this site for those who loves vintage building. Its like you enter a time machine. Bloody Awesome, Mate..

Royal Elegant look inside the QVB. Queen Victoria building is a unique mall having access to railway, road and Darling Harbour. You will surely get a good shopping experience and also some good food joints are there. The interior of the mall is very special with a royal look and mall is always having big crowd with little space to walk.

Amazing architecture AND shops to match.. Truly a stunning piece of Sydney architecture..the stunning stained glass dome is a sight to behold....an added bonus is the shopping and food outlets. Great for a leisurely stroll and a good coffee.
A little kitschy!. It is fun to walk through but we were not impressed by the stores. It is worth seeing for its renovated Victorian style.

Old world charm. Popped in here quickly for a bite to eat before a concert at the State Theatre. Saw it many many years ago when it was first renovated. Has lost a bit of it's sparkle. Had a quick dinner at Cellini's . A very nice Italian restaurant, great service couldn't fault it.
An architectural museum.. Built centuries ago, how they maintained the look is beyond me. Beautiful tiles, masonry work coupled with modern amenities just does it totally! A must see in Sydney!
BEAUTIFUL PIECE OF CAPTIVATING ARCHITECTURE. I loved to sit and have cafe there all by myself admiring the beauty of this place twice.Nice stores for luxury shopping,great cafe & chocolates

Come for the architecture if not for shopping. Architecture wonder. Such a majestic and well detailed victorian colonial building that sit in the middle of Sydney. It houses some of the great and unique shop (namely the moma new york store and the dr. Seuss store) in Sydney but, the main attraction is the building itself.Every corner of the building is great. The stained glass, the color and specially the unique custom build clock. Also they got this antique elevator to match the whole ambience!

A unique experience. Fantastic architecture. Quirky clock with unusual activities on the hour. And, a great selection of shops and restaurants. The QVB is different than anything else we found in Sydney. A classic, attractive building with a selection of, mostly, higher-end stores and a variety of restaurants combine to create a fun and different experience for a few hours. You may have to mortgage your house to afford some of the jewellery though. Worth a visit and pay attention to the clock in the center of the mall. Very unique.

Awesome shopping. It's not only a big shopping mall it's also a beautiful architecture object.Looks like GUM in Moscow (visit it).There are a lot of shops both luxury and simple.Good cafes on the ground floor

A must must must see in Sydney. Wow the architecture is incredible(in fact designed by George McRae......This was the original marketplace in Sydney.This is a wonderful stroll, do some shopping have a coffee......Its an incredible structure....You simply need to wander through this building.... A true landmark of Sydney!!!!!!!!

Upscale Mall in Historic Building. Nice multi-level upscale shopping with old caged elevators and relatively new escalators. I bought Haigh's chocolates and my son bought toys from Hobbyco. There is also a store that sells handmade historical figures at very high prices!

The grandchildren loved the beheading!. The QVB is a lovely old building with great shops and cafes. Our grandchildren ages ten and seven enjoyed the beheading the most. This takes place on the English clock and shows scenes from English history on the hour, including Charles getting his head chopped off. Go upstairs for the best view.
Good work of art. Good building. Very spacious yet expensive parking. Lots of good restaurants and shops lots ofbpeople a must visit when in sydney

I feel that I was in England for shopping !. Queen Victoria Building is the landmark for the Sydney of city ,which located in the City Town Hall . One of the exclusive shopping centre for the tourist centre. With all the exclusive and expensive ladies clothing ,jewellery ,watches antique products .I always go there to have lunch there to talk my business there or having bird watching tourist for shoppers. Most people go there are business people and high class business people go there . The building is so nice ! I enjoyed my meals there !

Amazing old architecture with excellent shopping. I loved the old architecture of the QVB and adore strolling through it to see all the wonderful shops and cafes all the way.You can walk straight into it from Town Hall station and wander along the levels and come out at Pitt Street mall. This gem of Sydney town is one of the last remaining reminders of old Sydney and we treasure it.. The shopping is amazing equal to anywhere in Australia

Fantastic architechture. Unlike most cities around the world, Australia does a great job of keeping its heritage and architecture alive. This is a fantastic example of a Victorian era arcade, on multiple levels, with a glass roof. Cant be too many of these around anymore, well worth a walkthrough.
Go back in time. Lovely old world ambience; takes you back in time. Good selection of shops and restaurants.You can easily spend a few hours in the building.
Expensive but worth a visit. No trip to Sydney is complete without a visit to QVB. This lovely old building is now bursting at the seams with coffee shops and designer shops.

Couple of nice restaurants . We stayed near the QVB. A beautiful building that was restored to its Victorian roots. If you are an international visitor check in w the concierge for a passport of coupons. After walking all day there were a couple of nice restaurants that were good for a light lunch. We shopped at Haigh's chocolatiers for gifts.

beautiful. Beautiful building, it is worth going inside just for a look and to see the clocks that hang from the ceiling. On several levels, there is a wealth of shops (some very expensive, and speciality shops). I went there for breakfast a couple of times, it is very pleasant. One day I found I had walked from the station into the QVB without going outside.
Simply beautiful. A beautiful historic building with beautiful stain glass windows and domed ceiling and tiled floors. The shops are great too!

A blast from the past with a modern feel. Amazing how well restored the building was. On the inside you'll find a plethora of luxury shops, to cater for any and all.Just above Town Hall station it's very easily accessible and is conveniently located, making getting there and back very simple. Across the road is Topshop/Topman and the Westfield building.

Gorgeous building .... great shops !!. Visited here a couple of weekends ago when in Sydney from interstate. The architecture was stunning .. as were a couple of the shops (Adriano Zumbo & the Swarovski Shop). Will certainly visit again next time I am in Sydney.

Love this place. When I first saw this building, I thought it was a train station. But it is too beautiful, I had to see it. We ended up coming here often to have coffee, window shopping, and hang out to enjoy its interior decor. It is an intoxicating mall. Must come to see their staircase, rose window, old style elevators, and floor tiles.

History and Modern at one place. QVB is if not the best then one of the Best Buildings in sydney with Historic Value to it. The transformation of History into Modern world is amazing as well. Form outside it looks great as an old architectural building with Queen Victoria's Status at the front of it (Town Hall side). Step a foot inside and you see a whole new world which is Buzzing. There are lots of CAFE's and Shops split into a few levels. QVB brings world's top brands into its embrace. Public Traffic is just amazing, from passer by's to people shopping there, its just non stop.If you visit Sydney, I would recommend a must visit of QVB.... aka Queen Victoria Building.
Worth Visiting. The Queen Victoria Building was a lovely shopping building that is beautiful and ornate and worth checking out!
Old palace in Sydney. One of the most beautiful palace in Sydney. Located downtown and full of shops and restaurants.Very nice place.I've been there in August 2010.

Nice old shopping mall. The place is near Sydney Town Hall, I think it just across Sydney Town Hall and there is a statue of Queen Victoria in front of it, I guess. And then after I come in, wow..the building is old and there are many luxury shops in there, the interior is vintage!! Must go there!!
Must see. Beautiful building, nicely restored, high end shops, really a must see at least once. And once there check out the unique clock in the north hall, I have never seen anything like it.

A touch of milano. Lots of small luxury boutiques in an amazing building, nothing to buy for me as the brands are pretty pricy but still nice to visit. The building from the inside remembered me of milanos boutiques and architecture.
Beautiful Building . Beautiful architecture and well kept. Lots of independent shops as well as tearooms. It's just nice to wander through too.
Killing time while waiting for friends. Lovely place to visit. It's like stepping back in time but with modern shops. The architecture is amazing. Really easy to get to from Town Hall Station

Once was a Parking Station, now a Star. Located in the heart of Sydney's CBD,the Queen Victoria Building (QVB) has had a chequered past. It has been a parking station , a City Library, a warehouse, none of which were the original intentions for this gracious old building. Then along came a wealthy Asian investor who transformed the bones into what it has become today: a multi-level upmarket shopping mall including fashion and dining with some specialty shops such as fine chocolates, home wares and jewellery; access point to Town Hall underground station; home of the ABC shop. In the basement you can find access to parking station. Upstairs you are right on a bus terminal. Across the road is the Sydney Town Hall. Nearby is the Haymarket and the Darling Harbour precinct. In the basement you can find a heavily patronised Asian restaurant specialising in Malaysian street food. Accessible by rail, bus and foot. Amenities coming out of its ears

Never gets old. No matter how often we are in Sydney we quite often find ourselves wandering through the qvb... All the shops and cafes have something to offer for all ages and some times we've seen some famous faces shopping with their families'!!! The clock in the centre is always a winner with everyone...

A grand old building. Queen Victoria building is such an institution in Sydney - has a prime position in the heart of Sydney with both historical and architectural significance. Whether it be coffee at Cellini's on the balcony overlooking the drop or some retail therapy, it is a stunning place that is hard to beat for sheer grandeur. The sense of history surrounds you no matter what you do here. It rivals the Galleria in Milan for this grandeur.

A must visit for Sydney. This is a lovely building to visit. Stop at many of the cafes on any one of the floors to have a cuppa or in dining. It is a busy building, so keep an eye on the kids , with escalators and stairs , so if you are tired, just take the escalator. There is many expensive shops, so here you will be buying or just looking. No in between here. But the decor is a must to see if only you stroll through.

European Inspired Architecture. European inspired architecture. It stands out because it is surrounded by modern buildings. It houses expensive shops, so if you are not into shopping, you may not stay long. A few pictures of the details of the architecture would be at best, the good thing to do.Close to the Sky Tower and a few blocks from Darling Harbour. There is also a train station there if you want to catch one.

Australian icon - go now. There are some great building and shopping experiences around the world, this is Australia's. Started out as the city vegetable market over 100 years ago, fabulous restoration to a modern shopping experience that respects it's past. Not entirely keen on the latest revamp, but it is still a spectacular building - not to be missed.
Every time I'm in the city. When I go in to the city I always get off at town hall and exit via the QVB visiting some of the shops along the way. My favourite shop is Lola for young adult clothing.
trip in a time machine. absolutely worth a visit to see the workmanship that went into this building...looks like new after a refurb some time ago.

Beautiful building. A great place for shopping with good diversity of stores, if you are looking for trending brands go to the other shopping, the Westfield, if you like traditional things, this is the place. The building itself worth the visit.

Absolutely stunning building with high end shopping.. One of the best places to shop on George Street. The building is not to be missed, with fascinating clocks and gorgeous stained glass windows. Many places to eat, and some very interesting shops.

Great Shopping and Food. I love coming to the QVB. I have memories of when it was being refurbished, and, as s child my favourite stores was Hobbyco. So now I can go and relive my childhood. Nowadays the QVB is a great place to shop for something special or yo meet and eat. There are plenty of excellent cafes that serve glorious breakfasts and sumptuous lunches.
Shop til you drop!. If you like retail therapy, Then thisw is the place to go. Excellent array of shopping available and nice cafes as well

A shopping center with wonderful architecture. Put your expectation on the architecture rather than the shops inside this shopping center. It definitely has a unique character in the building.Shops are ordinary and price is far from good from our point of view. I would not set up high expectation when I do shopping in Australia.Local people walk fast in the area. Maybe you can get yourself a cup of coffee, stay & relax to feel the atmosphere.Enjoy.

Shortcut if nothing else. This is a restored shopping building fill of stores and cafes. The architecture is gorgeous. Yet, the most practical part of the building is that it is an underground passage. The QVB links Town Hall Train Station to Pitt Street Mall. This passage is a great way to avoid rain, crowded streets, and the heat/cold of the day. All while seeing little shops that you can't see elsewhere in the CBD.
Shop, shop, shop. Building has great character and there is a fabulous range of shops. Right in the centre of sydney and we'll connect to public transport make this a fabulous place to shop

An extremely grand and beautiful place to window shop. This is the way all shopping centre/mall's should look. Grand and beautiful, love the central clock and the old elevator.Evoke's memory's of yesteryear.

Unique Building. This is a classic old building, but in perfect shape. The building is from the old centuries but the stores and restaurants are modern and trendy. It is like a nice shopping mall in a historical building.

Sydney Weekend. The Queen Victoria Building is a great piece of architecture. We walk through from the station. There are some wonderful shops but is not a good place to go with a toddler who is curious and wants to touch things. The clocks are and amazing piece of workmanship. There is a variety of cafe's that will please most people

Quintessentially Sydney. Fabulously restored, elegant shopping, don't miss the Luneburger Pastry shop near the entrance to Town Hall for great coffee and delicious German pastries. And don't go home without something special from Adriano Zumbo...everything in that cabinet is absolutely delicious!
Fun beautiful great Tea. Had a great walk through. Absolutely beautiful architecture had gluten free High Tea and enjoyed it all. Need to spend more time and do some shopping next.

Love the decor. I enjoyed the Queen Victoria Building more for its architecture and decor. The clocks are amazing, from top floor great angles of them closer up. Overall shopping here is just ok, not my first choice.

Its not what it looks like. When I was standing outside the building it appeared to me as a super old building and I felt that there would be nothing that i should waste my time on inside. As soon as I entered the building my perception of it changed at an instance. It was very lively and also, the cafe on the ground floor (forgot it's name) serves one of the best hot chocolate that I've ever had till now. There were all the possible elite and prestigious luxury brands one can think of. It was truly an amazing experience.
Good for shopping . Nice shopping building located in the heart of the city. Close to darling harbour, and located just outside Town hall station

Busy, but still has some charm. It used to be the icon of Sydney shopping however it has become extremely busy and a major thoroughfare for commuters which means, you can no longer really just 'stroll and enjoy the decor'. Great cafes up stairs though and great ambiance! Avoid peak hour.

Love the building, not the best place to shop. I loved the design of the building, it looks stunning at night, the shops inside were of average though, I wouldn't shop here in my opinion, had a great walk inside the mall, enjoyed it. Good thing is that the building links with the nearby shopping malls. Recommended!

From Market to Heritage Site. QVB started life as a market. But what a market. It has mosaic tile floors, a huge domed roof in the middle of the four story building, and a beautiful winding staircase with solid wooden balustrades leading from floor to floor.This was a statement of prosperity in the 1890s when it was build in the middle of what is now Sydney's CBD.In the 1980s, with urban development gone mad, developers wanted to knock it down and build a modern high rise. Such was the protest from the people of Sydney and the Workers' Union of Australia, that instead of knocking it down it was fully renovated and reopened in 1986 as a center for 180 boutique shops, with a food court in the basement.You don't have to buy anything when you go there (it is all a bit expensive). But just marvel at the glorious architecture and design of which was originally a common and garden meat and vegetable market.
Great architecture. This is a must see for anyone visiting Sydney. The shops are great and the architecture is simply amazing.
Home away from home. I love this place! There's a whole world of stuff here from casual cafes to fine dining restaurants to take out lunch, comfy chairs to relax on and free wifi.
Great place to visit. A great place to stroll through and shop/window shop. A bit of everything for everyone. I highly recommend Hobby Co as there is something in there for everyone.

Saved from being demolished for us to enjoy. For anyone visiting Sydney this is a must see. The shops are great, but its the architecture that is the real star. The mall itself is full of retail outlets and lovely places to eat. Visitors at Christmas can see the most amazing Christmas Tree which can be viewed from several floors. Its an active shopping area so its free to look around. Enjoy this building, as at one stage it was going to be destroyed for office development - we owe thanks to those who fought to save this gem.

QVB. Love the shops! Especially when they are on sale! There is a Victoria's Basement in the building and shopping for quality housewares and kitchen equipment on a bargain is a must-do for cooking enthusiasts.
Part of the free walking tour! . It is totally worth it. If you take the free walking tour you won't miss it. It has an incredible story and now it is a shopping mall.

Beautiful Building. Great photo-ops. Stain glass windows. The building now houses a very upscale mall. Reminded me of many such malls in the states. Several options of places to eat, many with tables out in the flow of traffic.
Must see in Sydney. You could spend half a day in here exploring the shops and architecture. The variety of retailers and the range of goods is amazing
Lovely building. So beautiful to see this historic building. Make sure you're there at the 1/2 or full hour to hear and see the clock on the top floot.
Stunning old world shopping mall. A very beautiful shopping mall with plenty of references to Sydney's history. It's pretty small but definitely worth the visit. I highly recommend Haigh's and Zumbo,

Wonderful building. Everything about this historic restored building is great!. The fixtures, the clock, the stores, the ambiance and even the restrooms are interesting. Don't miss it! I only wish I had purchased some Haigh's chocolates while I was there.

Amazing Restoration. The developers knew what they were doing when they restored the lovely old QVB. They managed to maintain the heritage of the grand old lady and while doing so attracted the leading brands as tenants. Of particular note is the mosaic floors which are spectacular;

Amazing building. The Great Australian Clock is one of the many fascinating attractions as you walk through this remarkable building. Not only are the speciality shops lovely but the architecture of the building is just as amazing. When my mum and I visited we found a lovely cake shop on the top floor that's worth a visit and we enjoyed breakfast at a great little open café on the lower ground level. If you're in Sydney for the shopping or just to sight see then you should definitely check out the QVB.

Decent Shopping Spot with some fine dining. QVB is a old building that is right next to the town hall station. As you exit the station you can find arrows to enter the building. You can find at the top floor few shops that can give you good bargain on Opals (Gem Stone). You also have couple of fine dining a toy shop at the top and few garment shops
Photographers paradise!. We always love coming to visit the QVB. We always seems to find things we missed from our last visit. It is a special place we have in our hearts.
Shopping the name brands. If you're interested in shopping for name brands than this is the place you want to go. It is expensive but if you go here to shop I don't think you mind spending money.

True Delight. A beautiful old building - that was a surprise to visit. I was fortunate to be shown around by a friend while visiting Sydney. We also had breakfast there, which was reasonably priced. The specialty shops there were also a surprise.

The "australian history clock" is awesome!. The clocks are amazing! Especially the australian history one! It moves with time.
Don't miss the underground path inside the QVB and the talking dog in the entrance.

historical & modern perfectly combined! fashion food & art.. Queen Victoria Building or Qvb as locals affectionately call it, is right in middle of Sydney city. its a beautifully restored old building, with old European style architecture. very nice stained glass windows, spiral staircase. visit during Christmas time to see the Swarovski crystal Xmas tree!! during other times of the year it often has interesting & quirky special exhibitions, eg flowers, or lights/ video projections onto the dome, or fashion & art exhibitions. 4 floors of retail therapy and lots of eateries including Tea room with high tea, Japanese & Chinese restaurants & coffee/cake/chocolate shops such as Adriano Zumbo/ Haighs/ Koko Black. Lots of desginer label fashion. as well as high street / chainstores to suit all budgets. in basement is huge Victoria Basement a homeware store. upstairs there is huge Hobby Co. they also have parking for those who drive. and its right next to townhall train station.
Stunning . I am not a shopper but this is a must to see while in Sydney the architecture is amazing, really enjoyed my stroll through the building

Beautiful architecture. This is a must! Yes it is a shopping centre but look past this and admire the beautiful building both inside and outside! Some great eating options including g high tea in the tea room. Wonderful!
Weekend indulgence. Th e architecture of this old building is beautiful, lovely yo walk through, sit and have a coffee and just enjoy the building.
In the heart of Sydney.. Located in the heart of Sydney, QVB offer an underground path to Town Hall Station, having a large number of stores and food court.

Inspiring example of Victorian Architecture that beats bland modern Malls!. Absolutely gorgeously restored building, variety of shops. Check out the centrepiece clock, Dr Suess gallery & the Tea Room (housed in what was previously the Grand Ballroom) Tea Room was booked out so we did High Tea at the Palace Tea Rooms & that was 5 star..numerous cafes to pause, take a seat & truly appreciate the talent (& mourn the loss) of artisans from a bygone era!I can't resist a visit to QVB whenever anywhere near. :)

Beautiful architecture. This building has some wonderful architectural aspects. You could wander around it all day enjoying its features. However, you wouldn't be coming here for the shopping unless you didn't have a budget you had to worry about. Expensive stores.

Architectural beauty - and so important. Why is architecture so important ? why is important that we do things right ? The QVB is an example of why. I understood from the delightful lady we spoke to for some time in the Dr Seuss gallery (yes that's right...head up to the top floor and get in touch with your childhood before you do anything else in Sydney) that the old market building was originally due for pulling down some time back. That's unlikely to happen now. multi level, full of the some of the best names in town with delightful cafe's and centrepiece clocks hanging from the central ceiling, the QVB is everything that shopping and society and architecture can deliver in a single double espresso hit. Beautifully restored and maintained, the Tea Room on the top floor is a must.....after Dr.Seuss and some shopping. What's so odd about me writing the word 'shopping' is that we really hate it generally in the general and otherwise soulless, lacking inspiration malls.

Beautiful architecture, tacky and overpriced shops. The Queen Victoria Building is a great piece of Victorian architecture in the heart of Sydney. Unfortunately, most of the shops inside are pretty tacky or overpriced. The best shop in in the basement, Victoria's Basement, and it is a great place to buy well-priced kitchen equipment.

great walk. We went for a walk through this beautiful old building it has everything you could want to look at especially the Royal Clock and the Australian clock please go and have a look for yourself just for the experience you won't be disappointed plenty of food and coffee places also.It was a highlight just being there.
Beautiful. Beautiful mall, variety of shopping options and a range of dining choices, from a light snack to High Tea.

Thank goodness this was preserved. even if you do not want to shop, this building is a worthwhile place to visit for coffee/snack/walk through. go to second or third level to appreciate the floors and clock. would also recommend Von Troska and Towanda as friendly places to shop

A Quaint, Historic Sydney Classic. weather its fine dining, coffee, Art or Boutique shopping your after, the QVB offers an assortment of all of the above, plus a Clock that all people young and old.. must see at least once.

Equisite archectecture. Elegance at its best a magnifique building. Designer shops with expensive products, still, nice to window shop! We visited purely to see the fine archecture. Certainly worth a visit to see grandure at its best.

Impressive historic building!. It is hard to believe that such a beautiful building was originally built for shopping and commerce. While it is stunning outside, make sure you also explore inside. There are endless shops and cafes on multiple levels. Look up and check out the historic clocks on display. Amazing place (near Darling Harbour)

Really Cool. This old building was really cool. I went to a couple of the old arcades in Melbourne before coming to Sydney as was quite disappointed. But this building was much better. Definitely worth a visit.

Georgous Building. Coming out of Town Hall Station you enter QVB. Many varied shops. From high end to budget. Clothes, shoes, jewellery, kitchen, lots of eateries. Sit down and takeaway. Haight Chocolates. Great Central Position. Beautiful building. Very busy!

Love wandering through QVB. I'm lucky enough to wander through the QVB everyday on my way to work. The decor is beautiful, both inside and out, from floor to ceiling. There's a wide range of shops to visit from T2 to Cue, Body Shop. There are so many lovely coffee shops, handmade chocolate and bakery's. Definitely worth a visit.
Beautiful building. this building was almost knocked down, fortunately it was restored instead, they have done it very tastefully, an excellent reminder of the Victorian era of Sydney

Great historical building completed in 1898!. The Queen Victorai Building or QVB as it is known was completed in 1898 and replaced the Sydney Markets on this siteThe Romanesque architecture was planned so the Government could employ many out-of-work craftsmen - stonemasons, plasterers, and stained window artists. This building fills an entire city block which includes George, Market, York and Druitt Streets. Trading hours for the lower ground and ground floor are 9am to 6pm Monday to Saturday and on Sunday 11am to 5pm.Trading hours for Level 1 and 2 are 10am to 6pm Monday to Saturday and on Sunday 11am to 5pm.Each time we are in Sydney we love taking pictures of this historical building and wandering amounts the various shops. Lots of great cafes and coffee shops with tables located in the corridors.

Love showing off this architectural beauty. I always make a point of taking my visitors through the QVB to see the beauty of the building and the stunning interior, not to mention that kitschy clock that everyone loves. My recent visit was with a friend who writes a travel blog. She loved QVB and took lots of pictures of the stained glass and the dome. Lots of nice places to get a bite to eat, too. We had brunch at the Jet Bar Caffe and the food was delicious. The shopping is a bit over-priced and very touristy, though you can find some reasonably priced items if shopping is your thing.

Beautiful Queen Victoria Building . This is a beautiful architectural and historical highlight of Sydney situated among modern high rises. Great place for shopping, lunch or a coffee. There is a wonderful antique map shop on the top floor with map treasures from around the world.

Beautiful Architecture. Simply beautiful architecture with amazing attention to every detail. It is very rich in history and we truly enjoyed the tour we had through the lovely old building and along the street outside.

Useful and elegant.. It is a beautiful beautiful building. Many shops that offer you a lot. Murials on the wall. Grand elegant clocks. And, the cafes look really nice . . . We'll have to try one one time for lunch!
Great shopping!. amazing shopping in a well maintained restored shopping centre. Everything you need, cafes, boutique stores and flagship stores all in one!

Step Back in Time to Fairly Average Shopping Experience. The QVB is a beautiful building with an interesting history. It seems almost out of place in the souless downtown Sydney CBD. It is a silent sentinel to a more gracious Sydney of yesteryear. In a city that cares little for the preservation of historical beauty, it is an architectural anachronism.Having said that, It is well worth a wander through - it has been renovated in recent times; however not to a high degree of historical accuracy. If you were travelling through Europe or the UK you probably wouldn't give a building like this a second glance. Here in Sydney it is on a short list of the more interesting historical buildings. The shopping options tend to be somewhat pedestrain and the tourists are catered for through tacky 'art gallery' options, etc. Visit at Chriistmas to see the beautiful tree in the central atrium.

QVB. A historical building used to be a market place, but now a up-class shopping arcade on level 1 to 3. The interior retains its beauty. The basement however is too crowded with shops commonly found in an average shopping mall. An excellent link to Pitt Street Shopping Street, Westfield, Townhall Square.

Downtown Shopping Mall - Gorgeous Buliding. This absolutely beautiful structure is home to four floors of shopping in an elegant and stately building in downtown Sydney. The central hanging clock is unprecedented and puts other mall clocks to shame (it is best viewed from the top floor). Look around to find the marvelous stained glass all around the building, even in some stores. Lots of escalators, stores, food, and history make this an exciting stop for visitors. There is a stop for this on the red line of the hop-on hop-off bus as well.

Venerable Architecture meets Classical Decor. Only went in there for a coffee, but the building is adourned by a grand entrance, a meticuously preserved shopping arcade feel, yet splendidly brought to 21st century standards - the best of 19th and 21st century splendour. Decent enough up market shops, open piazza style coffee shop - good java in an ornate setting where tranquility and harmony meet for an enjoyable experience.

Birthday high tea. I attended a friends birthday high tea for a significant birthday. The waiter explained the menus and were really good with allergies/intolerances.A very nice range of teas cofees and hot chocolates were available to choose from, unlimited during your sitting. Which was lo key as some places will only cap it at 1 pot if tea. Price was very reasonable. The teird tray of high tea good were just Devine.

high end boutiques but a beautiful building. you cannot miss this building when you are in sydney because it's so prominent and located right above the town hall station. if you like high end fashion brands, then this is your heaven. but there is a food court at basement, so you can lunch there too. i love the interior of the building as well, very european and colonial.
Beautiful old building. Beautiful for shopping, meeting up with friends, people watching. The tea room is exquisite and has the best high teas.

A trully magnificent building and a perfect Sydney meeting place. This really is one of Sydney's most spectacular buildings. Built between 1893 to 1899 in a Victorian Romanesque style and initially utilised as a marketplace. However, even as a humble marketplace the building included two impressive stained glass windows which display the arms of the city of Sydney. The building in my memory became very run down but after restoration in the late twentieth century the building has been returned to its former grandeur. Set in the centre of the city the QVB is great place to meet friends but while there do walk around the very top floor of the building which houses a fascinating range of odd ball shops.

Best place for coffee and cakes. the QVB has recently been refurbished and is an impressive building with many interesting shops. This is a great place to stop for coffee and cakes etc. Skip Costa etc and you will bowled over by the selection of cakes which are reasonably priced. Our favourite is on the first floor I the corner. Great service, food and prices

QVB Sydney. We visited the QVB building as my wife had not been there before. It is a very attractive building offeringgreatfacilties and a broad selection of cafes, eateries and variety of speciality retailers. Some of these are unusual and interesting, the map and print store, hobby store and jewellery stores were . The range of clothing was great and offered good differentiation against the usual shopping complex stores. There are many interesting features worth noting , the world clock, stained glass windows and period staircases were interesting. Well worth the visit .
Australia's most unique building. What a delightful experience walking through four levels plus basement of quality shops & eateries. There are 200 unique shops in this complex. It was magic.
Beautiful building. What a treasure! Loved this building. Great shops and eateries. So glad Sydney has preserved something so special.

Lovely architecture. The building is full of beautiful architectural details - iron staircases, stained glass windows, tiled floor design, etc. The stores are interesting to browse, e.g., the window display of Dr. Seuss paintings/prints. The on-the-hour-performance of the Royal Clock is interesting. The restrooms on level 2 are quite lovely!

Feast for the eyes!. The QVB is a truly magnificent building. The architecture, the stained glass windows, the dome, the clocks, the wrought iron work, the mosaic floors are all amazing and breathtakingly beautiful. All this besides some great shopping and good eateries make the QVB a must do place to visit for anyone visiting Sydney.
Beautiful Old Building. This stunning, restored old building in the heart of Sydney is full of charming shops. take your camera if you like old architecture.

Lovely building, heaps of shops. A spectacular, beautiful building with stained glass, curved staircases and other features. Many of the shops are boutique, and there are also some very good eating establishments.
Grand Building. A grand building that should be a must visit when visiting Sydney. Stop at one of the many cafes and enjoy a coffee while wandering the many shops.

Oh. So pretty. This is such a beautiful building. Be sure to get a photo of the dome in the middle. There some cafes and expensives shops around the building. The bus stops just out side and only a few minute walk to westfields mall and the tower.

Shopaholics Dream in a Stunning Building. The QVB is a beautiful building and it is a shoppers paradise with wonderful shops, cute cafes, and great holiday decorations. We spent at least a half a day in here shopping and eating, and we wished we had more time. The holiday decorations were gorgeous too. A must see.

A lovely place to visit. The QVB is a beautiful building with old world charm and is perfect for tourists and locals alike to have a bite to eat, shop, browse or simply take a nice stroll along the many levels. There's plenty of food outlets, cafes and restaurants to please anyone, and I love sitting at a café for a lovely coffee break after a spot of shopping. The QVB is a wonderful place to shop and browse through one of many specialty stores that sell anything from delicious chocolates, high end fashion and curios and unique gifts. Furthermore, the QVB also connects through to other shopping arcades and malls within the city centre. This is a great place to visit and a nice addition to any Sydney must do list.

grand old place. We even saw a wedding photo shoot in here! Always bustling and lots of interesting boutiques. There are some eating choices and this is a popular spot for locals and visitors alike. It is clean and seems well-managed.

Visit it. We took metro from the camping in Sydney suburbs and this building was our first step in Sydney actually. Really amazing architecture, nice just to wonder around but expect rather high prices even for coffee.
Shopaholic Paradise. This is an historic building full of beautiful shops to delight every taste, and wonderful coffee shops to satisfy your hunger and thirst, and rest your feet.

A must visit in Sydney.. You can catch a freebus that travels up and down George St and get off right outside this iconic late 19th century beautiful building.You can climb the stairs or ride to the third level in an old fashioned lift. On the top level is the beautiful clock with figures that move to music on the hour.Even the stylish loos are worth a visit.There are many well known names amongst the many shops- ABC shop, Aboriginal Art Galleries, Bally, Camper, Georg Jensen and The Metropolitan Museum of Art as well as many more. On the basement level is Victoria's Basement with many more shops but not so pricey.There are many cafes including a counter of the famed Adriano Zumba pastries.We sat a small cafe Parisi which was very busy. A toasted panini and a salad cost $14 and $15 so expensive but really enjoyed a chocolate dipped fresh fig ($3.50).QVB... highly recommended.

Make sure you stop and see this building. There aren’t a lot of buildings that take your breath away, but the Queen Victoria Building (QVB) is definitely one of them. Even if you’re not very interested in old, period buildings, you should not miss this one. The Byzantine architecture is incredible with beautiful stairways, arches, atriums, stained glass windows, woodwork, balconies, rails, domes, etc. The tile work on the floors is incredible and the paint scheme is amazing. The building went through different phases where it was a market, concert hall, city library, municipal offices and the current shopping mall. Again, this should not be missed and it’s free.

WORTH A VISIT. On my way to St. Andrew's Cathedral I decided to walk through the QVB, it was so beautiful inside I went on every level and I am glad I did , it was so beautiful seeing all the boutiques and eateries, I also cam across the ABC shop. Better then the Strand Arcade.

Memorable trip. Whilst in Sydney on a wet morning I took the Free bus from the door of our hotel with my 86 yr mother to visit this iconic beautiful building. We stood under the breathtaking stained glass Dome and took some lovely pics. It certainly has been kept restored in the Victorian era. We also had a nice coffee and pastry.

The grande old lady of Sydney. Once slated for demolition, saner heads prevailed and the QVB was restored. This was a brilliant decision that provided visitors with the ability to see this magnificent building. The shopping mall is fantastic with a great selection of outlets, there is a good number of cafes and the ability to connect with public transport makes this a must do attraction for Sydneysiders and visitors alike.

Magnificent!. Well worth the visit. Plenty to see and appreciate for all, whether shopping, looking for a meal or just relaxing. We had a wonderful breakfast on the second floor and spent time wandering admiring the architecture. And With the free bus service right outside the door you can move down to the harbour very easily.

A Must Visit Attraction. The Queen Victoria Building known as QVB is a major attraction for both tourists and local residents for shopping and eating. The building has a series of domes with exquisite stained glass windows and has 3 storeys. You will find some of the most interesting shopping in Sydney. The Romanesque building was constructed between 1893 and 1898.Pierre Cardin mentioned it as "the most beautiful shopping centre in the world". You must visit this place even if you do not want to shop. You cannot miss this building if you are on George Street near Town Hall in Sydney.

Beautiful building. Worth a visit to see this beautiful old building which has been lovingly restored. Wonderful stained glass , beautiful clocks, lovely shops. Lots of places to eat, love the tea room on the top floor for high tea and there is another lovely tea room in there also.

Steam punk, Victorian style . Funny but queen Victoria building exactly represents Victorian style. The clocks are nice. Almost every day when going to work I take time to get by the lift to the 4th floor and enjoy walking down watching interiors .

Lovely building, but a little upmarket for me. This is a beautifully maintained, grand Victorian building in the heart of Sydney, which provided me with a comfort break on my first walk down George Street to see the famous Sydney Harbour Bridge. The interior is stunning, plenty of wrought iron and stained glass, and full of upmarket brand shops. Although not really my place to shop, I enjoyed walking round to find the facilities, which when I found them were worth a visit in themselves - authentically Victorian, with smell to match the wrought iron urinals!

a perfect fusion of historic building and stylish commerce. It's absolutely a perfect fusion of historic building and stylish commerce. Along with the visiting of this ancient architecture, you may look around all sorts of shops inside it, and enjoy the tasty drinks and deserts as well. A must-go scenic spot for tourists in Sydney!
Beautiful Architecture. the Queen Victoria Building is beautiful with high end shops and cafes. I find most shops are high end and cafes are quite expensive. The QVB deserves a visit but that is all.

A quaint place in the heart of the city. Always love visiting the QVB - great shops and lovely places to eat and drink! Its nice to get away from the heat of the city streets and almost step back in time - make this a place to visit when you go to Sydney!

Come for the architecture, clocks, and the Haighs' Chocolate Shop. I'm not someone who takes much interest in shopping, especially at a high end establishment such as this; however, the QVB was worth visiting. The architecture is quite incredible, and the stained glass windows were a delight to (quietly) photograph. The clocks, featured in the reviews, are incredible. Last, but definitely not least, don't miss the Haighs' chocolate shop! They sell great chocolate and good quality mugs (which made a great souvenir).

Definitely more than a just a mall. Absolutely stylish, interesting architecture. Shops not "crying out loud". Lovely cafes. It has much more character than most of the shopping malls I have encountered lately (including those in Dubai).

Great high end shops in charming old world setting.. We always visit the QVB on every trip to Sydney. Although we always say that we are not going to buy anything we always do buy something and always are very happy with our purchases! A mus do visit for everyone visiting Sydney!
Nice. Wait 'til you steps inside and you'll know how pretty this building is. So much vintage look in a mall. Lovin' it.

Stunning old building that is now a very modern high end shopping mall. This is a beautiful historic architectural gem in a very modern city, hidden amongst the high rise buildings on George Street, you are pleasantly surprised once you step inside. The mall houses mostly high end retailers, but is well worth a visit just to see the beautiful ornate staircases, the well preserved mosiac floors, and the old lift that I believe is still in use. Even if you don't intend to buy anything, the QVB is a must see in Sydney!
Beautiful Building. The building is amazing! Beautiful architecture and looked stunning from all angles. Great shops inside and cute cafes.
Wonderful. Beautiful building with high end shops. Victoria's Basement is worth a visit for a great range of kitchenware.

Beautiful Building.. This stunning building is full of history. We did not shop here because the shops are quite high end. In this building the toilets are worth a visit even if you do not have to go! Also the toy shop is deffinatly worth a look in no matter how old you are! Lots of eating places to choose from too and the clock is worth a look, specially if you are there on the hour!

Beautiful inside and out. We loved this building. First, I should explain that it is a mall, with places to eat and great shops. However, it is full of history inside and out. Statues of Queen Victoria and her dog are outside ( and the dog talks!) and inside, you can see a "beheading" on the clock on one of the upper levels of the building. Also, the building has a basement which has tunnels that connect you to the metro and other tunnels that connect you all the way over to Pitt Street and Westfield Mall. We enjoyed coffees and salads one day, and it was so much fun! We also used the tunnels for a shortcut on a another day to get to Pitt street. Very nice place.
Best seen at Christmas. Don't go during peak office hours, you won't be able to move during the commute and lunch periods. You can meander all over the city, as there are many divergent corridors.

A unique and beautiful building.. In the 70s the Mayor wanted to demolish this building and make a concrete plaza. Ah, the building was still so beautiful, even boarded up, that for once the public got off their bottoms and saved it! Well done. It's really worth going just to look at the structure. For tourists it is totally full of shopping, food is all well done but usually a little pricey. If you can, then have high tea at the tea rooms. Well worth it!

Old Charm. The building itself always pleases me and I just enjoy wandering about it. A large range of good shops with unique little restaurants and coffee houses. We had a very good Devonshire tea in one establishment

GREAT MAKEOVER FOR A GRAND LADY. This Grand old lady started life as a market in 1890 but was completed restored in 1986 and now houses up to 180 high quality fashion shops ans high end cafes.It occupies a full city block of George Street The dominant feature is the mighty centre dome, which during the Christmas period is occupied by a giant Christmas tree, a must see for any visitor. Glorious stained glass windows and splendid architecture endure throughout the building and an original 19th century staircase sits alongside the dome.Tours of this beautiful building are available.

Wifi and a good desert. We got coffee, candy, and good pastries here while we stayed in Sydney. The WIFI is free and there were soooo many tourists taking advantage of it, sometimes it was hard to find a place to sit. They had some extreme price watches/ accessories that you could buy, but no one would give me 21000 AUD to get a time piece, so I'll just have to go off the registered prices. The stairs, clocks, and scenery were fantastic. I would go again.

High End Shopping. Lovely old building very well restored containing high end shops and great little tea rooms with horribly tasty cakes!! Nice way to while away a couple of hours, but take your cheque book!!!
Beautiful architecture. The building was recovered in an old world style which is beautiful. Lots of upscale stores and food, so you can Walt spend a few hours here. Don't miss it.
Best shopping in Sydney. This was just a great place to browse and shop, had a good couple of hours here and a lovely lunch. Public transport outside the entrance, had a really good day.

Stunning. Beautiful building, stunning stain glass windows, beautiful stores, great little cafes. Well worth a visit if you are in Sydney. Particularly stunning at Christmas with the huge Christmas tree extending across many floors.

Building worth a look at. We always visit this building when we are in Sydney, went back three times in the past two weeks.It's a lovely building to wander around. Cafes and restaurants are good. Check out the basement for some good specials in homeware.The toy/model shop at one end is always worth a visit. It stocks some great products that we often don't see altogether in one shop and has been there for a long time.

Fit for a Queen. The renowned Queen Victoria Building is very historical and has four levels of shopping Haighs chocolate shop from Townhall entry to boutiques, restaurants, cafes ,Hobbyco, Fat Buddah ,antique jewellery, The Gold Shops ,IM lingerie , Bally so beautiful shopping sounds like wedding bells ,no but there is royal clock with the sound of trumpets on the hour so you know how long you've been there . Enjoy a coffee at Metropole or yum cha at Fat Buddah, great any time of the day, car park available so easy to get to by train or bus on George St . There's so much to see and do shopping , high tea lunch all under the famous dome .
A stunning building. In Town in business and wandered through after a meeting. Wow. This building has been beautifully restored and the architecture is fantastic. Well worth visiting.
what a beautiful building. This building is just wow!!! Go inside and explore it (not the shops, just the architecture). We just loved it, reminded us of the GUM shopping mall in Moscow.

This place makes the nearby Westfield seem soulless!. Yes the shopping on offer might be expensive but what great surroundings full of personality & character....givee this over a modern mall any day!

Cool architecture - expensive shopping . After a local friend recommended, I had a walk through this mall. The architecture was stunning, and made it worth the visit. The shops are expensive, high end stores, but there are some gems in there. Example: hobby store and the stationary place.

Wonderful renovation. The building has been given a 1st class renovation and is in pristine condition; a guided tour is available. The shops become more exclusive and expensive the higher one goes, but the top floor is worth a look even if just to window-shop. The cafes also become more expensive with elevation, from ordinary cafes on the ground floor ( perfect for breakfasts) to ultra-refined, waitress-only ones up top. The stained glass windows are beautiful, and at Xmas the Swarovski-sponsored tree was magnificent.

Made me feel at home .. Beautiful shopping arcade with lovely caffe's as well . Popped in here several times whilst visiting Sydney . I think I was feeling a little homesick and found it very comforting . Lovely small and classy boutique shops .fabulous architecture ,loved the clock .

You will either love it or hate it.. What to love. shopping, shopping and shopping with lots of food stalls, it is connect to the town hall train stop. A old historical building that is quite exquisite both inside and out, but if go during the middle of the day, the place is mobbed and it loses its charm. either go early or go late to a more relaxed view. the store are quite pricey so mostly you can go for a look. If you at the town hall station then go for sure, but otherwise, if you have explored everything else in sydney, then it might be worth it if you have to check off every last attraction. otherwise it is not an "essential."
Stunning building. The building is beautiful and worth seeing even if you don't fancy the shops. Although having said that there are some lovely shops within.
Beautiful building and great shopping.. I found the hard tiled floor hard on the legs but i loved the shops and the fact there was an Adriana Zumbo outlet and a Haigh's chocolate shop!

Magnificent Shopping Arcade. Even if you don't need to buy anything, you'll enjoy a stroll here just for the sights and sounds. Make your way to the upper floors for cafes, and to see the fantastic clocks. A great way to see high end shopping in Sydney.

not too special. honestly, it is not too special for us other than the old lift. We can't buy anything inside while most things are too expensive.
It is alright to take photos outside QVB or try the lift... needn't spend a lot of time there.

Historic & Beautiful. The QVB as the locals call it is a beautiful history antique building located in the middle of Sydney and can be accessed via Town Hall Station. The buildings offers plenty of cafes, shops and restaurants. The great history of the building is present via the antique decoration throughout the building. On the top floor there is an unopened letter from Queen Elizabeth. The letter is not to be opened before 2085 (I think). The building also has a few tunnels, and some hidden ones connecting different parts of the area including Pitt Street.
Beautiful building. The building itself is beautiful, amazing architecture. There are plenty of shopping options around but it is bery busy.

Beautiful Old Building. It's amazing what can be done with an older building. This shopping mall was renovated so tastefully, we could enjoy just walking through without intending to shop. The shops looked expensive but there seemed to be plenty of people in them. There is a beautiful large clock in the center and many other features that make it worth a stop/look.

Beautiful building.... Beautiful old building----converted into another mall. The difference is beauty and style of the architecture, stained glass, iron-work and arch-ways. You're in the area anyway, walk another block and check it out!Be warned: after the above, it's just another mall filled more of the same-similar shops and eateries that you'll trip over in every other mall in the area. Of course, I'm not much of a shopper!

Old Victoria Charm. The outside facade of this building has excellent Victorian architecture. It contains a lot of options for shopping with brands from world over. there are a few interesting eateries/cafe which one should try.

Wonderfully restored building great atmosphere. We visited the queen Victoria building twice during our visit to Sydney it is beautifully restored with lots of the original iron work and sky lights. We ate at a nice Chinese restaurant called vama. Make sure you look at the interesting old mechanical clock in the upper level.

Must See - and try tea or lunch here. This is a must see attraction which will remind you of London. The tea, sandwich and bakery shops and restaurants are perfect for late morning coffee, lunch or high tea.Husbands, grab your wife's credit cards as the shops are top notch. There's a hobby shop up on the 3rd level that kid - and fathers - will enjoy!I stop by here nearly ever trip to Sydney - so about once a year. Across the street is Woolworth's where you can get your Tim Tams at a great price to take home to family and friends - or horde them for yourself!

Beautiful building. This is a gorgeous building to look at and although it is now a shopping centre it is still very grand inside and out. Some nice shops are located here and the little cafés were busy. Well worth a visit

Stunning! You have to see to Believe!. Stopped in for a look around and was amazed. From the outside it gives no indication of the beauty inside. Stained glass and ironwork like I have never seen. Great coffee and pastry shops along with a few restaurants and some great high end stores. Check it out.

Iconic old building. Being such a young country we don't have the old buildings of Europe. This one is special with it's stained glass windows, the dome as on some European buildings. It is in the centre of the city with many cafes, beautiful shops. At Christmas they have the tallest Christmas tree adorned with Swarovski crystals going through the different levels of the building.The birdcage where Santa sits is like fairyland. You have to see the large clock as it strikes on the hour. Gorgeous! I love this building at any time
Nice old building. Beautiful building, expensive shops.A only a pity that from the outside you cant see how beautiful it is.Inside beautifull old features, and the big clock is an eye catcher.

Stunning.. We had been told by quite a few people to visit this building so we did so. It's a very large shopping centre and whilst inside is very clean and modern the outside is very old fashioned and traditional. There's also a monument of Queen Victoria outside the building.
Worth a visit. This and the Strand Arcade are reminders of a bygone era.There are some terrific shops and places to eat - lots of fun and style.

Beautiful Building with High End Shopping and Good Food Court. We enjoyed walking through the building, which is amazing. We don't shop much while on vacation and not at high end stores so that part of it was not helpful. We did find the food court to be good with a variety of food available and comfortable seating.
Short cut. You can travel from Meyers store to the town hall underneath the QVB building cutting out the need to dodge the traffic and the weather.

Quaint and charming. From the statue of Queen Vic and her dog outside the the clocks inside that put on a show on the hour. This shopping centre on the grounds of the former sydney market oozes charm.The shops are high end but the building itself is lovely, there are little tunnels underneath that lead to nearby shopping centres which just add to the charm. The view of the entrance by the Hilton is also quite nice.

Queen Victoria building. The outside of the building is heritage, inside is full,of very small very expensive shops. Don't like the inside at all. It reminds me of a market but much better set up. Not my type of shopping centre.
An absolute must!. The building is iconic, the shops are well worth looking at and the flair is just second to none. Don't miss out on this Sydney landmark.

Historical feel with modern shops. The architecture on this building has been nicely preserned as is the dome but the shops inside range from little boutique stores and homemade chocolates to your usual more well known modern shops. Prices are mostly reasonable. Nice places to have tea and a good variety of food outlets. Connects to Town Hall Station. At Christmas its beautifully decorated with a sparkling Swarovski tree. And don't forget to wait for the hour and watch the clock.

Shopping in Style!. Gorgeous building with echoes of the Victorian era. Great selection of boutique style shops and lovely restaurants. Toilet facilities are good too. Christmas is a dream for the little ones.

Blast from the Past, A Must Go !!!!. A yesteryears building now converted into a shopping extravaganza is not only beautifully maintained but shopping in here is absolutely delight.Located in the heart of city , just few steps away from darling Harbour, it is situated near the best signature brand stores.Do not miss out this experience, you'll love shopping in here for brands viz. Bally , Salvatore ferragamo, Ralph Lauren etc. Also various cafes inside the QVB. Are just so invigorating , you'll love them too.

Excellent Visit. This is a beautifully restored building with high end shopping and cafes. I loved the colorful tiles floors. I stopped to eat in a cafe on the end near the statue of Queen Victoria. It was a great people watching location.

My favourite place in the CBD. Why is this my favourite place? Well it has everything from designer stores to Haigs chocolate. Located in the heart of the CBD, the QVB is a must go! It draws crowds of people on a daily basis. Filled with upcoming fashion, trendy cafes, good eats, some of the best chocolate and Victoria's Secret. If you haven't had Haigs Chocolate before - THAT IS A MUST! The architecture of the building is just beautiful. The train station is located at the bottom of the building also. I love this building. If you are in Sydney, the QVB should be on your list of visits.

Lovely Shopping. This building is gorgeous which is why I went but of course did some shopping. Didn't have too much time so I can't speak too much of the shops but there are lots of them. And lots of eateries as well. The architecture is so amazing its fun to just walk around even if you don't want to buy.
favourite place in Sydney. This is my favourite shopping centre in Sydney. Not cheap but a wonderful range of shops and lovely cafes. Worth a visit when in Sydney even just for a look.

lovely shopping and cafe. another place where you can just spend hours without getting bored .so much to see i.e. the building which is so beautiful ,then all the shopping and food.lots of pics to be taken here

A gorgeous building from the outside, but go inside. On my last visit to Sydney, I was impressed with the exterior of the QVB and took picture after picture. But today, I stepped inside, which is like stepping back into 19th century England--the interior is awe-inspiring. Even the ladies lounges are elegant. A must-see! They should offer walking tours of the building. Just explaining the stained glass windows, the wrought-iron gratework, the tilework, and the two massive ceiling clocks would make for some interesting historical trivia. Take time out to dine in one of the cafes in the building.

Still beautiful and elegant, a true Grand Dame. Each time I come to Sydney, this is a must visit. Love the design and architecture, the space and daylight streaming through. It's lovely to sit outside one of the cafes, enjoy a coffee and just absorb the ambience.Love to browse the many shops, checking out what interesting food offerings there are. Very tempted to try the chocolate covered fruits...quite a wide variety from the normal strawberries to mango, banana etc. The Haights chocolate boutique has an amazing selection of chocolates that just tempt to pick up a pack of everything.

Impressive..... The building is very beautiful, and inside you find one of the finest shopping malls in Sydney. Very delicate decoration and something for the eye - even though that you don't swip your credit card..:-)

Superb architecture - "Jewel in the Crown". What an amazing building, historical with a great variety of shops in the city centre.We both enjoyed trawling through the shops and founds some bargains.The building was clean, as were the shops, a credit to all involved.Definitely worth a visit, and we will be back.

Stunning to look at, shopping is optional.. A beautiful restoration of a Victorian gem. There's a lot to loathe about Sydney CBD architecture, but you won't regret wandering through the QVB and searching out some of the hidden details, like the amazing restoration of the top floor ladies bathroom. Food options are generally unexciting and over-priced, I imagine the rent is very high, but there is no compulsion to eat or even shop here, just soak it all in.And at Christmas there is always a stunning tree in the central vestibule (although often accompanied by some live music that never seems to really work for the setting). Enjoy!

Crowded and Stifling. I wish we'd skipped a trip into the Queen Victoria Building. I wanted to see the building itself, but the mall was so overwhelmingly packed we couldn't see anything. There's almost no signage or people to direct you to the area you're looking for. We tried to wander around but were pushed like salmon heading upstream. Unless you're a hardcore shopper I'd skip it.
Gorgeous. This was so much fun to visit. It was like a step back in time. Fabulously interesting place. A definite must when visiting Sydney. The wife loved it too.

Back in time. this beautifully restored building is a must see when visiting sydney. Packed with specialty shops, food hall and even its own train station. Situated right in the heart of the city. Make sure you go next door to the Sydney town hall another historic attraction.
A beautiful building. With good shops, nice cafes and a nice atmosphere. Not your usual shopping centre. Located above Town Hall station is another benefit.
awesome architecture. A nice and old, well maintain english building, with many stores. Kind of expensive but hte most interesting part aside from the vitreaux, is the QVB sub terrain shops.

History and shopping. We love this historic complex, great for window shopping and plenty of choices for coffee or tea. If you are looking for a special gift you would most likely find it here from antiques, leather, clothing, toys and in the basement we found a great factory outlet selling china and other kitchen items at bargain prices. Make time for a visit here.

Great for gifts. If you are looking for gifts such as towels or opals head upstairs to the top floor and work your way down. Also look in the ABC store for some great books. If you are hungy, go to the bottom level and grab a snack.

Up-market shopping in historic building. We visited the Queen Victoria Building on a recent trip to Sydney when the very popular Swarovski Crystal Christmas Tree was on display, and it was a spectacular sight. There is a nice selection of up-market boutiques on the various floors, plus various eateries. There are public toilets on the upper floor of the building on the Town Hall end, which were a bit hard to find. Escalators and lifts convey customers to the various levels of the QVB. The basement area has various other budget priced boutiques and outlets and links to Town Hall underground Railway Station. Featured in the building are the Royal Clock designed by Neil Glasser which has English scenes, and the Great Australian Clock designed by Chris Cook which has scenes from Australian history.
Nice architecture, trendy shopping center. Ideal place to shop if you get paid in bags of gold coins. Top end shops with top end prices. Stained glass and building design are worth a look.

Historical building mixed with shopping and great facilities.. This building is a marvel. Built in it's hey day and still standing. It's historical and has many historical little shops and eateries, and is a sydney icon. Do take the time to walk up the stairs and go up to the higher levels. The stairs have been very well worn, and I swear if you stop and listen you can probably hear ghosts.

Breathtakingly Beautiful. The Queen Victoria Building located on George Street, Sydney is breathtakingly beautiful. This up market shopping centre is located on 4 floors around a central atrium. With ornate clocks and fittings this is a beautifully preserved building from Sydney of the 1800s. There are shops, restaurants and even a real old fashioned lift and when we visited a giant Christmas Tree which was situated on the ground floor with it's top on the fourth floor.
Plenty of shops in a beautifil building. The building has been turned into a wonderful shopping centre with lots of up market retail outlets.Always worth a visit !
Variety. Always a good place to shop or just browse. Lot of the shops are expensive - just for the tourists but there are little pockets for the sydneysiders. Our favorite shop is Florentine

Much more than a high-end shopping centre. The QVB is as classic and impressive piece of Victorian architecture as you'll ever see, occupying a full city block and topped by a massive copper dome. It's worth having a look around the exterior before venturing inside for another perspective on its grandeur. Thanks partly to the many upmarket shops, if anything its interior is even more opulent. There is magnificent detail in stained glass, stonework and wrought iron. And to think that before the building's top-to-toes restoration in the 1980s there was talk of its demolition. Once you have admired the building, there are many and varied shops to check out across four levels, including plenty of coffee shops and cafes. Except for many of those on the underground level, which can be a frantic pedestrian thoroughfare to/from Town Hall Station, virtually all the shops are beautifully presented. It is a wonderful place for a wander and a gawk.
Queen Victoria Building. A very olde world shopping precinct, unusal shops and restaurants, a wonderful clock overhangs the ceiling a real centre peice, a lovely Victorian tiled flooring.

great building. go for a look even if you are not shopping. The christmas tree and santas area were very impressive!
great area to shop, bit of a maze. Also interconnected with the other shopping malls

It's beautiful but .... The QVB is a stunning building with 100s of beautiful shops but you better take your credit cards because your cash won't last long!
The building really is beautiful and even if you go to simply window shop the atmosphere is electric.
Lots of lovely eateries catering to all tastes can be found mostly on the lower level.

Beautiful shopping Centre. If you like retail therapy then this is the place for you to visit loads of high end stores + lots & lots of coffee bars. You can then walk through and go into George street which is full of shops and also Malls. I have never seen such a concentration of shops in one place absolutely amazing.

Beautiful beautiful beautiful!. Where does one start? QVB is just absolutley amazing! There are about 200 shops and the place was just crowded with a fantastic atmosphere! Just love this amazing building with so much character and right in the Sydney CBD! Have been on several occcasions and will be going again soo when back in Sydney!

Classic & Timeless as ever! Great Cafes!. My first encounter with this beautiful building was about 20 years ago in 1994. Back then I was an excited 20 year old out in the big wide world going shopping with my friends at Queen Victoria Building in Sydney, boy how cool was I!. As a I had grown up in a small country town, you can imagine how totally "in awe" I was of the whole experience and the feeling it gave me just being there. I remember eating at the trendy cafes and just walking around for hours gazing through windows at some of the most beautiful clothes I had ever seen! Fast forward 18 years into the future about 2 years ago, I visited there again on my trip to Sydney. In all honesty I was absolutely astounded by the timeless, classic beauty of this fabulous iconic building. I was also very impressed that in 18 years, this shopping centre had exceeded my expectations in retaining its former "Glory!" The shopping, cafes and overall experience were not only what I had remembered it to be but so much better!

QVB - Handy and Trendy. Haighs chocolate right at the ground floor entrance at the Town Hall end on the corner of George and Druitt Streets . Heaps of other shops to choose from. Well worth the window shopping as well.

Nice Shopping Plaza. I visited the QVB thinking it was going to be a historical site, but quickly realized it was a shopping plaza. I guess I should have read the reviews. The QVB offered great shopping and eateries. These stores are extremely overpriced.
shopping. wow what can i say but if your in sydney get to the qvb its awesome full of history and full of great shops its a must

Stunning. Beautifully restored building inside and outside. Inside there are lots of little specialist shops beautifully decorate with period lifts and fittings all over. The Christmas decorations were also up when we visited (Nov'13) which highlighted the place even more.

Beautiful building, high end shopping. Originally a market, this building suffered from neglect until it was renovated starting in 1984 at a cost of $86 million. Inside are three floors of high end shops, dining and beautiful glass, wrought iron and two large mechanical clocks. This is a great place to stroll through with lots to see, and if you have enough money, even buy something.

Nice Quaint Building. The fascade is very interesting but most of the inside has been refurbished and very modern. We like the old elevators and the clocks that were preserved. Many cafes and restaurants inside. There is also a statue of Queen Victoria outside the building at the south end. You can reached there by riding the free shuttle service 555.

This building made my Christmas. We walked through this lovely building at dusk and the lights (all blue) were on and the Christmas tree was lit up with Swarovski long crystals and lights and was just a picture. The whole building is a lovely old building which has been restored to cater for very expensive and elite shoppers, but at night the shops are closed and tourists can wander through and gaze in awe at the restoration.

Excellent experience. Coming from Dubai, where there are numerous shiny new Malls it was great to see something old world that has been brought up to date. As it is the festive season, it was also nice to see the effort had been made here to get in the spirit. Lots of different and unusual shops, some great cafes serving good quality coffee and snacks. Something for everyone here from the food court in the basement through to the top end boutiques and jewellers. Really enjoyed spending a good part of a day here, and within walking distance then of the massive Westfield centre, as well as short walk from Darling Harbour. I was pleasantly surprised as well how clean and well kept everything was, even down to the public toilets.

Magnificent Architecture. We know this building as the QVB and it was completed in 1898 to replace the original Sydney Markets. This building has many levels, from the busy basement concourse and shops that go from Town Hall Station to the Myer complex. On the upper levels you will find a wide variety of small boutique shops and cafes. You will also find the Palace Tea Room where you can have high teas!.If you like historical buidlings....this is a must in Sydney!Make sure you check out ALL the levels, not just the busy concourses!

Charming. The Queen Victoria Building in the heart of Sydney is very charming. It has retained it's original look but still managed to blend with modern Sydney.It is a four-level shopping complex. Complete with some dining areas, apparel and fashion stores and other merchandise. Most of the apparel and fashion stores are branded. What I love most about this place is that it is not too big and you can easily find the things you need.I recommend this place to anyone who will visit Sydney. Whether for shopping or not.

Town Hall Station. Love that Town Hall train station exits into the QVB. An amazing underground & above ground shopping and eating "presinct" I'll call it. Lots of options in here from cheap to lah de dah! A favourite place when I visit Sydney.

Step back in time for enjoyable shopping and eating experience.. Thank goodness the forward thinking city council of Sydney had the foresight to save this amazing historical gem of a building, I visited here the week leading up to Christmas and the atmosphere was spectacular with the grand walk ways and shops festooned with Xmas decorations, There are many specialty shops not seen elsewhere in the city and the choice for Xmas gifts was abundant. The coffee shops and restaurants located on most floors were buzzing with customers and many tourists were snapping pics of the massive Christmas tree which towered for three floors to the very top of the historical centre dome. Stay around for the chiming of the musical clock suspended from the ceiling to watch a historical pageant of English history.Well worth a couple of hours enjoyment and people watching in great ambiance.

A shopping centre with a difference! Victorian charm and character. Shopping all around the world is the same, but not here. The building is stunning and very charming.
