There is many shops and a wide variety of places to eat and get drinks. There is stained glass in the windows which is beautiful. The shops have great sales and there are many different shops. There is something for everyone, even those who normally hate shopping!

Nice mall with great shops. A bit Britsh alike but atually an American style high end shopping mall with garments, chocolate, porcelein and more. Very impressive christmas decorations and therefore the most beautiful mall around. Sorry Westfield ans Sydney Mall but this one is by far the most posh mall of you all ;)

Wow-wonderful architecture, have a coffee and enjoy. This grand old building is a very lovely shopping centre-quite high end but worth looking through and do not miss Haigh's chocolates. The building has an open area like many shopping centres and you can sit at a table and have great coffee and cake and marvel at the architecture, stained glass and tiles. As one review said check out the washrooms with the lovely original tile-all different and the elevators are cool-there are more than you think as they are tucked around corners. Great toy store for puzzles of Australia to take home. The escalators are modern and you enter from a glass platform which is a super contrast the the history of the building you see. All my days travels seemed to end up here-and check out the chocolate covered fruit at the coffee place on the main floor.

Shopping in style. This shopping mall is full of history and opulent fittings. It really is a beautiful building which has been well restored. The Christmas tree is huge and many were taking the opportunity to photograph it. There is a huge variety of shops and restaurants/bars to keep everyone happy. Plenty of parking available also. If you have not been here you should definitely take a look.

What a place to shop!. Old world charm, amazing shops, an absolutely beautiful place to shop in the heart of Sydney's CBD. Take time to have a coffee or a meal and enjoy this beautiful building and all it has to offer.
Nice building. Great location right near Town Hall in Sydney. There are better shopping malls nearby but QVB is worth a visit.

Beautiful building and great shops.. Even if you're not buying anything, definitely worth a visit. The building has lots of character and the shops are in a unique layout. Lots of good Aussie designers on show too!

First class shopping experience. Sydney's QVB is full of expensive designer specialty stores. Lots of clothing shops, Australian jewellers, and the like. There are some cafes as well. You can enter the building underground from Town Hall train station. Watching the clock feature suspended from the centre of the shopping centre attracts many tourists as it strikes the hour. The historical building is beautiful and is worth walking through in your visit to Sydney.
A building of such distunction. Some see it as a retailing hub but first and foremost, it is a grand old building of incredible colonial architecture - one of the best examples still surviving.
Amazing Architecture!. The shopping mall and tourist attraction Queen Victoria Building has it`s own amazing charm which is absolutely unique! Great building and great colonial architecture.

Beautiful!. I love to visit the QVB during the festive season because the Christmas tree is amazing! The building is beautiful with lots of shopping and dining option. It is high end so shopping doesn't come cheap but a trip to Sydney wouldn't be complete without a visit to this iconic location. It is easily accessible at street level but also by the railway which runs below the building.

Back into Victorian era!. The building architecture is a beautiful, the entire place has an antique look. At 6 pm daily a big clock hanging from the third floor ceiling ticks and ..................................... A suspense!Wait till you actually see for yourself what happens! Enjoy the look and feel, and shop if you desire.

Beautiful. This building is full of things to look at.. From the shops to the architecture.. Top floor hobby shop has an awesome window train display. There are plenty of shops that are full of original little gifts... The lifts are quite a great ride as well.. Look forward to the clock chiming on the hour hanging from the roof...

Shops, NICK-Nax and curios. You can trudge the Pitt Street stores and then browse the floor s of this centre to find some trendy boutiques,jewelers specialty-shops fast food, and some museum curious. Plus you can navigate the underground accesses to other main streets of the CBD and the metro rail link.

Great historical building . This is really a great historical building in heart of Sydney with excellent shopping options. However the highlights of the building is the clocks...yes multiple clocks on the building, wait for the right hour and see them come alive on the top floor.
Must see for all visitors and permanent resident of Sydney.

heritage and shopping to suit all. Start at the bottom where it is cheap but plenty of cafes and slowly climb to those shops at the top level where you can window-shop.
It has been restored immaculately - the decoration is truly victorian and has been well preserved.
A must for all visitors and is accessible by rail or bus.

Christmas at the QVB Building. The Christmas Tree at the QVB Building has to be the most magnificent in Sydney. The tree extends through three shopping floors and is decorated with 15,000 Swarovski crystals. Each floor is decorated with Christmas lights over the balconies, making for a beautiful display. Make sure to look at the Royal Clock which has 6 scenes of English Royal History which activate hourly between 9.00 a.m. and 9.00 p.m. daily. The QVB building was built in the late nineteenth century and is one of the best preserved buildings in Sydney. A joy to visit at any time of the year but particularly so at Christmas.

Lovely building. The QVB is really beautiful to walk through and "window shop". Of course, purchasing can be done, too - especially if you want good quality items. All the floors have very special shops/stores. You can have lunch, a snack or coffee as there are plenty of eating places there, also. It is particularly lovely at Christmas when there is set up a great Christmas tree and other decorations magnificently displayed.

Gorgeous for every age. Head to the top floor to watch the clock displays on the hour, kids have loved the changing dioramas of English and Aboriginal Australian history for decades now. Don't miss the Dr Seuss gallery on the same level, it's kid-friendly and reminds you of a literary great that takes you back to childhood.HobbyCo boasts a large model train set in the window that kids love looking in at - and the fancy toy stores on the same level make for excellent window shopping. On the bottom level is a bustling food court, while the other level is a mixture of high street fashion, cafes and speciality stores. At Christmas time, the Swarovski crystal tree is not to be missed - and the fairy-light adorned Santa room looked magical. Even if you're not shopping - this building is a stunning example of early Sydney architecture and should make part of any itinerary.

Very colourful. All the Christmas decorations were up and shops etc decorated, As this must be one of the most noticeable building in Sydney it was very tastefully done . still lots of old style about building remains including the wonderful clocks inside.

Makes you feel like you are in Europe. The Queen Victoria Building (QVB) is one of Sydney's most important buildings. Located right smack in the heart of the CBD, the facade of this magnificent building evokes a sense of European timelessness. Once you step in, you have that feeling that you are in some part of Europe, with its classic looking architecture. The place is huge, and you can easily spend 3 hours just browsing the shops or having a bite at any of the cafes. Do visit the two giant hanging clocks and see how it moves every minute. With a classy place like this, expect prices to be above average too. As the Christmas shopping was in full swing, the children had a fun time taking photos with Santa.

Shopping in a Grand,Ornate Style.. This Beautiful Shopping Centre Which was refurbished some years ago now,to the tune of millions of Aussie dollars,is a must see attraction with I think something like five levels,The ornate Victorian style with its beautiful tiled floors,and Period styled shop fronts will keep you on your feet browsing and buying no doubt for hours,and when your through shopping,just pop down to the basement level where you will find an array of Cafeterias and eateries to Refresh your pallet,Every time I'm in Sydney we always make time to visit the QVB as it it is known,and allow ourselves a few hours at least to marvel at this wonderful shopping centre,You will not be dissappointed.

Historical jewel in a landscape of the bland. The QVB is one of those places that just makes you breathe a sigh of relief for its very existence before you've got any further. Sydney is not blessed with a vast array of historically significant buildings other than those at the harbour so it's nice to find somewhere that has a welcome bit of class. The QVB exudes old school chic the like of which harks back to the old days of huge department stores and things built for aesthetics rather than mere expediency. The tilings are stylish the layout open the floors a joy to walk on. The clocks are great. It's the sort of building that wouldn't be out of place in Knightsbridge! Spent many a happy afternoon sat drinking tea and people watching. It's nice that they also have seating areas without you having to buy something.Oh and there's a great little fresh baguette sandwich place down at the bottom near David Jones if you can find it.

A Magnificent Mall. I went to QVB alone during mu trip to Sydney. My goal was to find some goodies for my sisters back home. First thing I notice, the building's architecture and design are impressive. So much like you are in Europe when you see the details. Next time you notice is the shops arround. You will relize that the mall consists of so many shops, ranging from food, sport apparel, fashion, jews and gemstone, and also its antique stores at the highest story. I found a great vintage bag for my sister in the highest story for only 99AUD. My sister loves it so much, and with the quality, the price is indeed worth it.
Queen Victoria Building (QVB). Magnificent example of Victorian architecture a must visit in Sydney. Apart from the architectural merit of the building there are lots of upmarket shops and cafes

Described by Pierre Cardin as the most beautiful shopping centre in the world. Very rich in history and architecturally splendid, the QUEEN VICTORIA BLDG, occupies an entire block on Sydney's George St. Has over 180 of Sydney's finest fashion boutiques, coffee shops ,restaurants, designer shops and so many more. The dominant feature is the mighty mega centre dome. you need to go to the third floor to have a really good look. And now that is Christmas time, there's the SWAROVSKI Christmas tree from the street level that reaches the ceiling on the third level. So magnificent and breathtaking! A must to visit for every travellers. If you're having coffee or dining or having high tea, this is the place to be, very classy and comfortable and there's something for everyone

Victorian Architectural Masterpiece. The QVB runs from the corner of Market St down to York St and is also accessible from George St. It is located parallel to Sydney Town Hall. The building was lovingly restored following a long battle with those who wished to tear it down. The large bronze statue of Queen Victoria at the York Street entrance was shipped to Sydney from Dublin, Ireland. Inside the building, there are the original cage-style elevators, as well as cedar and porcelain tiled stairwells running from the basement to the top floor. The basement offers a variety of cooked food suitable for a light or heart lunch. It is connected to the subway at a Town Hall station. An array of stores fill the ground floor and the top floor is upmarket with a range of boutiques, coffee shops, and one if my favourite places:.the New York Museum of Contemprary Art Gift and bookshop (The Met) . Overall, it's a great place to shop if looking for something classy or to just relax with a coffee. Most of it is air-conditioned. Even more appealing at the height of summer!
piece of art. Sited at the heart of the city with breath catching historic design, I loved the huge clocks hanging down the ceiling, nice caffes as well inside.
Stunning. worth a visit for architecture alone don't need to buy anything decorations were beautiful go in the old lift too
SHOPPING. Like:I like the Clock and the Christmas Tree. Staff are very friendly. You can find most items in QVB or just cross the street.Dislike:N/A

Great Place for Shopping, or a Break from It.. The Queen Victoria Building is a beautiful, beautiful building, with an impressive exterior and an even more impressive interior. Particularly now, when they've got a three-floor high Christmas "tree" under the central dome. (See photos) Awfully nice place to do holiday shopping, or to refuel upstairs with coffee or tea for the next lap on your shopping course.

Stunning - both inside and out!. The exterior architecture is grandeose and the interior has to be seen - it has been beautifully restored over the years and now features impressive floor tiling: ornate staircases; leaded windows and dome and a magnificent clock. It is a shopping cntre (on the posh side) but you cannot miss a visit here and I'm sure you will be as impressed as we were with the architecture and decor. If you're not shopping then simply have a coffee and admire the views!!

Fabulous surprise. I knew nothing of the Queen Victoria Building but was blown away when I stumbled upon the QVB. The beauty and magnificence of the building really took my breath away. The exterior is fabulous and the interior gets visitors back to a grand old era when builders took real pride in their craftsmanship. Inside is stacked with high-end shops and as I'm not a shopping fanatic it didn't attract me so much except to imagine the grandieur of past architecture and design. Don't miss the sculture of Queen Victoria just south of the QVB, which actually once stood in Ireland and was purchased and transported to Sydney in 1947!

Love this grand old building. This is not your typical shopping mall. The outside façade hints that this is a special place but it's the inside that has the “wow” factor. Kudos to those who restored this building as they kept some great original features including the staircases, lifts, wrought-iron balustrades, stained glass windows, domes and tilework (tessellated and mosaics). The glass roof allows natural light to illuminate all four floors of this amazing building. Take a couple minutes and check out the quirky bathrooms (try not to linger too long and freak out those using them). The famous "Royal Clock" and "Great Australian Clock" are also definitely worth a look. Yes, they also have shopping. There are many little boutiques and some large chain retail stores in this building in addition to a wide choice of cafes. While enjoying coffee and pastry at Cellini’s Café, we were amazed by how busy it was at 2 in the afternoon on a Tuesday in the middle of winter. It is clearly a great place to come to do a little people watching, or some shopping, or enjoy a coffee, or just admire the architecture. Highly recommend a visit here for whatever reason you fancy.
Lovely lovely place. QVB is really exciting place. Beautiful shops. Nice cafes. Just lovely to have a walk around. And when you are done, train station or buses are very closeby.

OVB The Old Dame Very Much Alive. Queen Victoria Building has an interesting history. At one stage it was the bottling and cellar facilities of Lindeman Wines. It operated under a number of different guises from housing warehouses for the home handyman, haberdashery et al. It was in a state of neglect for a long time until it was re furbished during the 1980s. It now houses many retail stores on a number of levels, it is a short cut to town hall station and china town, during Sydney's hot summer it makes for a nice short cut.There is a statute of queen Victoria sitting at the entrance of QVB. Pop in have a look see, take a short cut, walk pass town hall, which use to be a cemetery until they relocated the graves.
Old and beautiful. The building is an old and beautiful modernized building with exclusive shops. An under and over street level experience.

Iconic. Its hard to believe that back in the 1970's they wanted to knock this iconic Sydney landmark down. Dodged a bullet there as Sydney would be that much poorer had that plan gone ahead. If you love classic Victorian architecture you should probably check the place out. if you love classic Victorian architecture AND shopping you should definitely check the place out. From there, you can go underground to the Pitt Street Mall with funky little shops all the way

Great Shopping Venue.. Beautiful just to walk through. Great places for a meal and great shopping as well. High end shops to browse through. If you like to shop in a lovely environment this is a must do for every Australian visitor.

Once beautiful, now gauche.. While visiting Sydney, we were led to believe that this was a "must see". It was impressive on the outside but, once inside, it looked like any mall that you've ever seen if you've visited one in North America. While the ghosts of the past's grandiose architecture still whisper, albeit feebly, they're drowned out by the gaudy window displays and wait staff transporting food truck level cuisine to people all too willing to overspend on underwhelming food.Enjoy it from the outside, stick to the two uppermost floors and then head down to the Quay for more enjoyable experiences.

Beautiful building. QVB is a really nice mall to shop at. The architecture is beautiful. You can't miss the building when walking on George St. Lots of shops and restaurants/cafes in it. Only downside is the lack of public sitting areas.

Architecture/shopping. This building is one of Australia's great architectural masterpiece. It's a great walk through. Aside from the aesthetics, it is also a great place to shop. Lots of choices of high-end brands.

Amazingly beautiful building and a great shopping experience. The QVB is one of the better shopping complexes (if you can call it that) that I have been too. The building is amazingly beautiful with plenty of high-end outlets set up for window shopping. You can easily spend 30 minutes - 1 hour just strolling through but perhaps allocate 2 hours if you're looking to splurge. All the same, I strongly recommend taking a stroll just to capture the architecture.

This is a landmark. Check it out. I think it was 1986 when they reopened Queen Victoria Building. Prior to that restoration the building was derelict for some time I believe. Since then and relatively recently it's had a paint job. Australia is a new country founded only in 1788, as such there are not a lot of old world cultural buildings. The QVB as it's known to sydney sightseers, is our grand dame. On the west end of the buildings entrance sits the large imposing statue of queen Victoria herself. The building itself occupies one block and sits between George and York streets in Town hall. The entry/exit into town hall station leads you into the bottom level of QVB which if you keep walking through will eventually lead you to the major Pitt Street mall shopping district. QVB is grand in style and as you go up the levels the shops become more expensive. The middle is hollow so from the top you can see the bottom levels. Lots of charming cafés and antique shops. It also houses two major clocks that go off on the hour. Worth checking out. Taking pictures here is a treat. Lots of curves and stain glass. At Xmas I think QVB Has the best tree in Sydney. The only other building that matches it's charm but on a smaller scale is the strand arcade further along George st. Oh yeh Sydney has a thriving busking scene. The uber talented ones are generally featured in Pitt st mall. The ones that don't make that cut often end up sharing their gift with the world next to Queen Victoria as she glares down on all the mere mortals.
Wonderful. Beautiful archtecture inside and outside. So many details to pay attention to. In the heart of Sydney. You must see it

beautiful architecture with shops, cafes. Convenient location, good shops and cafes, with a fantastic food court in the basement. Nice simple place for those in the central business district (CBD). Some of the venues have seating in the internal atrium so you can enjoy the architectural views.
iconic structure. this is an iconic building, the interior is just fantastic and i love walking through here even just to look at the architecture.there is numerous stores to shop also.

Attractive old building. This building has been well maintained over the years and I'm always impressed each time I visit Sydney. There are plenty of shops to choose from inside, although don't expect to find too many bargains!
High Tea!. Definately recommend the High Tea here. We had the Traditional, Cocktail and the French Champagne High Teas and it was amazing. Staff are so friendly. I will definately be returning.

Wonderful piece of architecture...great shopping. This iconic building has been lovingly restored into a quality shopping centre.Plenty of quality outlets and big brands.Worth of visit if only to window shop !
Beautiful building. A must "walk through" if ever in the area. Such a lovely piece of Australian architecture and history!

Building is great shopping not so much. I love this building its amazing and relaxed and so well kept. However for a shopping centre they have very specificly targetted shops like the hobby shop and gifts and trinkets and high end clothes and handbags. They also have the high tea on the top level I didn't have time to try it but next time I will make it a must do.

Oldest shopping centre in the world - so they say. This shopping centre is so beautiful. There are some cute little shops to wander about but really just to walk through and appreciate the architecture and design is what is best. There are some really cute little cafes to eat at but as we had just eaten we didn't get to try any which was very disappointing. If I had known I would have tried something at one of them. Just so beautiful to visit and right in the heart of the city in George Street so easy to get to. Even my teenage sons appreciated it.

Beautiful place... shopping so so. The building itself was amazing. The clocks were beautiful and the woodwork was stunning but the shopping...not a fan. Alot of the stores I can find back in the US so I didn't want to waste anytime in them. I am on the other side of the world, give me some good Australian stores to shop in. The prices of clothes in the stores were inflated. For a tourist, I am not sure who buys jeans and then says oh I bought them in Australia. Maybe this mall is only for locals but when I think of shopping I think of local handmade crafts.

Shopping Exciting and vibrant . If you want the feel good and excitement of shopping in the Sydney CBD then the Queen Victoria building has it all. A great range of shops, services and food, vibrant, exciting and a beautiful building as well, I loved this place.

Despite the beauty it was a disappointment.. On my most recent visit to the QVB in Sydney I felt really disappointed by the Sydney City Council's lack of toilet facilities in the area. Whilst there are two places, at each end of the building, only one was operational and even that had a non-working toilet. NOT good enough for me or to encourage visitors.

expensive but beautiful. Theres plenty of shops and really sweet cafes and restaurants throughout. The building and architecture itself is stunning and look up. If you need anything expect to pay real money for it no bargins that Ive seen. But again it is nice to just sit with a coffee and appreciate the skill that went in to the structure

Spectacular Building. A beautiful building in the heart of Sydney that's been well looked after, when you go in the entrance be sure too look up and appreciate the design and architecture of the building.Lots of great shops and food so you can spend a couple of hours shopping and eating in such a pleasant building. A wonderful stop while in Sydney.

Very nice experience, some good/some not so good coffee shops, and excellent shopping!!!. This is an amazing building in the heart of Sydney. Great shopping, with the superior floors for designer labels, and the underground for cheaper, but still stylish stuff. Some great caffees and some not so good ones. Still, if you go on the 2nd or 3rd floor, sit down and enjoy a drink and a cake at one of them, as the atmosphere of the building is worth it, no matter how bad the coffee and how stale the cake (can't believe I just wrote that!!)

Shop + eat in a late-Victorian arcade. We're fortunate this heritage building has been preserved, well maintained, and converted to a shopping mall. With its multiple levels of eating places and shops, there are offerings for all budgets. On my last visit I spent my time in a large home wares emporium looking for Christmas presents. The shop's proximity to Town Hall station was a bonus. First-time visitors: you may find the low levels too hectic, as there are a lot of pedestrians hurrying through to get to their public transport or workplaces; you'll find the higher levels more relaxing.
lovely building. the building is beautifully renovated and conveniently connected to Town Hall Station. In the basement there is yummy German bakery - they have the best sandwishes in Sydney!
Still vibrant. Great example of Victorian Architecture and great to see it is vibrantly used. Good shopping and food precinct. Lovely clock and dome.
Great shopping. A lovely building to do a bit of Aussie shopping in right in the centre of Sydney. A great Ugg boots shop there.

Most beautiful mall I've ever been to..... Parking was kinda weird! It was like parking in a cave but once we got inside it was amazing. Stained glass windows and black wrought iron spiral staircases are not your usual fare in malls! Loved it! The Adrian Zumba macarons were To Die For!

Wonderfully quaint building within the concrete jungle.. We decided to walk through the QVB on the way back from Madam Tussaud's. Lots of levels filled with high end shops and two wonderful clocks. Either side of the middle staircase and two lovely stained glass windows and a brilliant dome overhead.The high light for me was Peter Nathan's Toy Soldier store. For any hound boy that loves models, military, history or toy soldiers this store will have you in rapture.Well worth a walk through.

Spectacular and lovely shopping experience. QVB is a such a grand building, that you really must visit to appreciate its beauty. A shopping hub for all shopaholics. Its in the Sydney Central and very near to the Town Hall station. Has most of the brands. There is an awesome bakery and cafe on the second floor, a must try. Also, it has awesome chocolates shop on the ground floor. You can taste chocolates there.

A little bit of England in Sydney ;-) . Loved this place. It's classic Victorian style is a must see on a trip to Sydney. Eat in one of the many cafés for a good price and nice food. Spend time browsing the shops or people watching. A great experience.

Victorian elegance in the 21st century. Unfortunately I cannot claim to have spent as much time to take in the sights of the QV building and its' shopping arcade as I would have liked. Being part of a 'Follow Me' walking tour of central Sydney, we only enough time in and around the building to understand some of its elegant style and significance in Sydney's history. The external features of the QV are a treat in themselves, requiring at times, a walk to the other side of the street to take it all in. The quirky, 'talking dog' wishing well near the main entrance is a busy tourist attraction. Entering the QV building you cannot help but be impressed with the style, light and colour of the shopping areas. Elegantly curved wooden handrails adorn sweeping staircases leading to wrought iron walkways and a glass and ironwork pitched roof. If you visit only on an organised tour as I did, do as I did and keep one ear for the tour guide's talk while at the same time grabbing as many photos as possible.

Wow.... Just wow!. We didn't dare shop in the building, but just to walk through it was amazing. The clocks in this building we incredible, I can't describe them, I don't have the vocabulary but suffice to say a trip to the building just to see theses is worth it!
Iconic building. This is an iconic building you do not want to miss. Shopping here is good too. Check out the basement for discounted home ware. Interesting!!

always calls me back. I've been to Sydney three times this year, and always visit the Queen Victoria Building. It is handy to anyone staying in the CBD - because Town Hall station (underground) exits directly onto the Lower Ground floor of the QVB. There are many low-cost eating places, and further up the levels of the building, there are some lovely cafes and tea-rooms. Also lots of expensive shops - but mixed with more affordable shops also. The building itself is delightful - a step back through the history of Sydney. It is so Central - that is one of it's most appealing features.
As majestic as Queen Victoria herself. A magnificent 19th century shopping arcade, with stunning art glass, ironwork, tiles, clocks and other decorative details. Go and gawk.
Magnificent. The QVB is a such a grand building, that you really must visit to appreciate its beauty. So many lovely shops to tempt you as well.
Worth a Visit. A truly magnificent building that now house shops and restaurants on many levels. The architecture both inside and outside is worth the visit.

Queen Victoria Building (QVB). Like a journey back in time to the old covered 'arcades' in Victorian England (where they banned whistling because it was a way for pickpocket gangs to communicate and exemplified in Dickens' 'Oliver Twist').Beautiful, air-conditioned and full of shops, as one would assume from a shopping centre, but from someone who hates shops and shopping, it's still worth a visit all the same!I was actually here in 2003, but I couldn't choose that option from the 'date' option. It may have changed completely in more than a decade, so beware!
Beautifully kept building worth a visit. A great majestic building worth a visit to see the wonderful architecture of the late 19th century. There are lost of shops to look at as well.
Magical Place. Number one building in the city for me... Take the time to go up a couple of levels and check out the clocks, just grand.

Great for food and shopping!. QVB in Sydney is a must-visit when in the city. There's hundreds of shops, specialising in fashion, food, art, electronics and much more! If you're not interesting in buying things, even just walking inside the building is enjoyable. It's also in the heart of Sydney CBD, which means it's easily accessible by trains and buses. Highly recommended for everyone whenever in Sydney!

Great Heratage Building:. Cant miss it, such a great building and fantastic shops, you can easily spend an entire day in the complex, l always visit each time l go to Sydney. If you like antiquity then this place is must see, the inner building is spectacular.
A must to visit. Such a gorgeous building and fantastic collections of branded shop to satisfy your shopping fever. Don't forget to take a look the premium chocolate store right at the main entrance.

Pretty Building.. Worth a visit to take photos of the building and its interior design. Shops are not quite to my preference and it is a little confusing while walking the basement. The basement links to another shopping mall too.
Great place to browse. Lots of high end shopping in this building, lovely to browse through and an amazing hand made chocolate shop !

Great shopping. Amazing looking 4 story shopping mall located in close proximity to everything. The architecture of the building is amazing. Heaps of shops including Victorias secret and Zumbo macaroons. The bottom floor is very busy especially is peak hour times, the bottom floor is connected to the City rail lines. Best shopping and a must do when in Sydney.

Shopping in Queen Victoria Building. Queen Victoria Building is also a place of interest for visitors of Sydney. It is nearby Town Hall station. This is not only a building to watch, actually it is shopping mall. You can enjoy shopping in historical building.

" a distinctive shopping mall". The Queen Victoria Building (QVB) is a busy 4 floor shopping mall that is connected to the City Rail lines on the bottom floor. Everything you need is available for purchase here and it can get very busy with foot traffic during the commute hours as the eating --- to go foods are located on the ground floor connected by the City Rail lines. You will be moved along with the constant flow of foot traffic moving one way on the left side. The shops get more expensive as you head up each floor. Must see the distinctive stain glass windows in the middle of the mall as well as the Australian and Royal Clocks which can be viewed the best on the 4th floor-- the do ring on the hour and the figurines in the clocks come out or revolve around the clock. Lot of small little boutiques that sell unique clothing or items. Good to window shop here. Honestly, the QVB was our lifesaver on an early Saturday morning when our attraction reservation was cancelled without notifying us. We needed to look for a possibility for breakfast around 7:45 a.m. and we did not want to return back to our lodging. Everything on George St. was pretty much closed with the exception of McDonald's and Hungry Jacks, but luckily I remembered the QVB ground floor that had all the various eateries available, not noticeable from the street level. Go for a visit if you have the opportunity. Definitely not the type of shopping mall you would find back home.
Classic!. What an amazing looking mall. Such grand interiors, very picturesque. Good brands, a few Australian brands as well.
Brillant architect. What a lovely building, shopping nice too! Real old Victorian building loved it! Lots of shops food ok

Exquisite building!. A friend and I spent the afternoon checking out the exquisite Queen Victoria Building and its excellent shopping opportunities!The shops are great and the building is stunning! Definitely check it out if you can!

Majesty in a building. . What a beautiful building! To think that it was once derelict and there was even a movement to tear it down. It is beautiful, from the tiles to the stained glass. Of course the shops in here are not usually the cheap ones, but they are of a very nice standard. There are several tourist type shops that sell Australian souvenirs that are a cut above what you can buy in most parts of town. There are many eating places and a couple of wine bars. It is not just a place for tourists, the locals use this daily. Don't forget to watch the magical clocks chime in the hour and do their little performance, then go downstairs to Haigh's chocolates for a little treat, start with the dark chocolate mint frogs. Then wander the building looking at the beauty of what it is and remembering what could have been.
Beautiful building. In the heart of the CBD you will find this. It's a great place to wonder around and window shop and people watch. Some ok coffee shops but expect a lot of people on weekends

History restored.. To think they were going to knock it down!It is one of the greatest late nineteenth-century buildings left in Aus and has been beautifully restored.A collection of who's who in fashion retail outlets.Don't miss a breakfast in the cafe on the ground floor. There's a reason it's normally busy.

A beauty in the heart of Sydney!. It's a world class place to shop! So many shops, beautiful petite shops. You are spoilt for choice! The building itself is just beautiful- the architecture, design and decor. The cafes and eateries were great! A lovely place to spend your day and your money! Would definitely recommend.

Would benefit from longer opening hours. Sydney's late night shopping night has always been Thursdays.I was there on a Friday night about 1930. The shops were closed.While the cafes were in some cases open, the shops would benefit from longer opening hours. This is of course a matter for the NSW State Government as it regulates such opening hours. Compared with Melbourne, however, it's behind the times.That notwithstanding, this is a stunning building and glorious to walk through, with the presentation of the whole centre and its shops first class. Access via Sydney Train's City Circle line is easy.

GORGEOUS!!!. This place by far is the MOST Beautiful and Gorgeous Shopping place we've ever seen! Stunning decoration, historical, everything was just (again) Beautiful!! Such an Amazing Building! And I have to agree with the other traveller :
Simply Exquisite!!!!

Simply exquisite. Admittedly, I spent little time at the QVB during this trip, but this visit caused me to wish Brisbane had a similar heritage building for all to enjoy. The clocks are a delight to observe, amazing cafes, even the statues on the south end of the building are there for our enjoyment. Modern art just can't compare to the amazing statues crafted by craftsmen of old.

I don't even like to shop -- but this is simply so much fun!. What a lovely treat in downtown Sydney. Beautifully styled building with stylish, higher-end shops and nice places for coffee and sweets. I don't even like to shop, but found myself just wandering the length of each floor marveling at the variety of stores, the color scheme and decorating of the building, and enjoying the ambience. Very much worth a visit.

Hours of happy wandering and photos. This is one of my favourite places to shop in the world as well as the most beautiful. With its ornate ceilings and staircases. It caters for all wallet types from the flowing to the tight amid various levels. This also includes an amazing food court with a dizzying array of cuisines to suit all palates. First class dining in a first class shopping experience! It's the best at Christmas time with the huge tree and gorgeous Swarovski crystals hanging everywhere. A great photo opportunity awaits.

Gorgeous historic building. One of my favourite places in Sydney. Covering a full block, this beautifully restored building features stained glass windows, patterned tile floors and a huge central dome. The two mechanical clocks are fascinating with both the Royal Clock and the Great Australian Clock showing historical scenes from English and early Australian history. The shops are mostly high-end retailers like Coach, Longchamp, Ralph Lauren and my personal favourite, the Metropolitan Museum of Art shop. If it suits your schedule, there are guided tours of the building on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays.

Beautiful Victorian building full of great shops and cafes. The QVB has been beautifully restored and it is wonderful to wander around and check the architecture. The glass stained dome is the centre piece with its gorgeous metal winding stairways. The main feature is the clock on the top floor where a large crowd gathers on the hour to watch all the movements. A large array of shops and cafes - something for everyone. You can spend a day here just wandering around looking. There is parking underneath which on the weekends is not too expensive for the middle of the city and so easy.

One of Sydney's oldest buildings - worth a visit, even if you don't plan on doing any shopping.. Built in the late 1890s and given its stunning splendour both inside and out, it's hard to believe at one point prior to restoration it was being proposed to demolish it. There's a mix of stores and smaller cafes. And at Christmas time, the decorations - in particular the tree - are a must see.

Beautiful building. The is a big statue of Queen Victoria in front of the building. The shops close early in winter. There was a big sales at the basement of the building now. All the cooking pots, knifes , cutlery were at 50%-70%.

Visit Queen Victoria Building in Sydney. The QCB is a magnificently designed building & a great architectural example of its period. It has 5 levels, is rectangular in floor plan layout, with beautiful stained glass central dome & side windows. The roof either side of the central dome is glazed & the spaces are cathedral in form extending from the lower lever through each floor to the glass roof. Around each floor are located a series of shops selling, in the main, quality merchandise of a variety that will challenge you to discipline yourself because if you don't it will cost you a bundle of $$$$. The food outlets are well appointed offering a range of food styles at reasonable prices. It's also a great place for people watching.

Victorian Age. No doubt this is one of the main attractions in the city.Victorian style designed building. A castle look alike.Those who love design and achitecture, this place is worth a visit.P/s: Remember the hanging clock!!! (visited in 2008-2010)

Beautiful Upscale Shopping Center. An upscale shopping center with plenty of Victorian elements to keep you enthralled between window shopping and having tea. There are four levels to this old building and each floor has unique decorative or functional touches you won't find anywhere else, like a fantastic clock hanging from the ceiling, a winding staircase, stained glass, etc. Besides designer labels, there are tea shops, an old-book shop, even a Metropolitan Museum store. You'll know the center by the huge statue of Queen Victoria that guards the block.

Such a beautiful building to enjoy. My husband and I recently had lunch at Cellini's with some relatives visiting from NZ. The restaurant was busy and we enjoyed a very nice lunch and then had some time to take in the Queen Victoria Building beauty.It is always great to walk around and either window shop or go into various shops.
Beautiful! . The building's architecture and interior is soo beautiful. The royal clock becomes alive every hour until 9 pm. It's such a delight to watch! Go shopping while you're at it. :-)

A truly remarkable building.. We visited the QVB when in Sydney recently. From the outside it is a truly beautiful piece of architecture. Inside has three levels of boutiques in Victorian splendour. The centre pieces are two fabulous old clocks one of which tells the story of discovery. The shops are very interesting including the Doctor Seuss gallery. Really worth a couple of hours.
Beautiful building and great shops - February 2014. This place was a really pretty shopping mall and had some great shops in it. The chocolate shop was especially nice!

Architecture at it's best.. As soon as you enter this building you can feel the life of it. It's architecture is fantastic and love the way they have maintained the fittings and layout. Oh by the way you can actually shop there as well but I just go to experience the building albeit my wife loves the diamond distributor just as much.

Somewhere in Time. Going to the Queen Victoria Building is like going back in time. The Victorian architecture, the old clocks being displayed, old elevators, and every the old (gentlemen's) bathroom are all unique. It is unbelievably well preserved.

Eat here but don't shop here. Most shops here will charge nearly double the retail to pay for elsewhere to pay for their high leases . Great restored building so enjoy it over coffee but i wouldn't shop here!

A work of art. I love the QVB. I wouldn't say that I shop there as such but I love walking through the beautiful levels and admiring the tiled floors, the stain glass windows and beautiful big domed ceiling and the clock centrepiece. There is something lovely about the light within the building and the sounds as they echo up through the levels. My favourite thing to do is wander along the levels and in and out of the many high end shops then I usually stop for a coffee on one of the higher levels and just sit and people watch. It is a piece of history right in the middle of the Sydney CBD and I hope that it remains so for many more years to come. The spiral stairs and small elevator are the originals from the late 1800's when the building was first opened, the whole building is a fantastic glimpse of architecture from this period. Highly recommended.

QVB - Heaven. My wife and I were tempted here for two or three days of browsing and snacking. This building is a renovated original that would have been demolished in Toronto. We loved the energy in the building and the mix of locals and tourists shopping. I particularly liked the jewelry store with the "cel phone free area" sign on the door. We shopped and snacked from top to bottom more than once and enjoyed visiting with the retail merchants that always had relatives or friends in Canada. A great place to wind down in the city centre when you need a drink and have time to shop or just people watch. Don't miss it if you're in Sydney.

Character. With modern structures sprouting here and there I commend whoever runs the QVB for not replacing it with a modern one. It has retained its charm. Old buildings have character and history. Nice to walk around and visit the shops. Its a high end shopping place. We were able to buy a few things. There are many food places to eat. But we still ended up in a Chinese restaurant. Overall experience was okay.
Sopping. Not bad to walk around shops ,food and under cover if cold, On a few levels but easy to get around , older style building which was good to walk through

QVB is a "must see".. This delightful building is such a great place to visit.Interesting retail outlets all independent,a lovely change from "Westfield"style run of the mill shopping centres.Lots of great eating places and coffee shops.You could spend hours here and never tire of it.
Great !. Wonder the different levels of this lovely shopping place.Fantastic boutique shops in wonderful victorian architecture

What an amazing building!. I can't believe they ever thought about knocking this place down! The architecture is amazing. It took me so long to even get into the building as I was trying to get a photo of the floor tiles in the entrance without anyone standing in the way. Then of course I had to get a photo of the dome in the entrance hall, then the spiral staircase leading up to the dome - was I ever going to get in here? But I did and it was amazing. Other the looking at just the archiecture, there were shops I was interested in but I didn't buy anything. Can't forget 2 amazing clocks. I thought one was going to do exciting things at 12 nooon so I hung around until then but nothing happened. Had an amzing lunch in the Old Vienna Coffee House if you can call champagne and cheesecake lunch! Even managed to get great pics of the toilets before I left!
Lovely Historic Building. The QVB is a marvellous example of colonial architecture. Inside are many boutique shops and eateries.

First Impression Lasts. Accompanied by our hosts, this is the first attraction that we had visited while on vacation in Sydney, and they have not failed us. Fascinating, well maintained architectural landmark; fabulous shops. We are lucky to see a tableau hanging at the center with significant plots accompanied by narration and music.

Shopping at QVB. Love shopping here when we are in Sydney, great mix of shops. Especially love Victoria's Basement, if you are not from Sydney bring an extra case there are just so many nice things to buy in this jam packed shop.

Dynamic shopping. It really takes you back in time when you visit the Queen Victoria Building. The architecture is fantastic the shopping is awesome. It is one of my special places to visit when I am in Sydney.

Very special men toilet. The men restroom is in the 2nd floor. You must visit. The coffee shop in the 1st floor has taste cake and good coffee. Besides shopping, you can try my suggestion. Having a good coffee and visit the restroom.
Worth the wander. Well worth the wander at any time to soak up the design and atmosphere of this interesting old building.
Beautiful building. Walked in to take pictures...thought the building was just stunning. Had tea and coffee at a very nice little shop and just people watched. Great shops, fun place.
Lovely building. We were amazed how old this building is. The design itself and the old clock is so amazing. A very elegant and interesting building. Such a very lovely building

don't bother if you're busting.. QVB seems to be on many tourists' agenda. It used to be a wonderful Victorian gallery but was spoiled by hideous clocks with automated figures and escalators that detract from the grace of the original building. Now they have decided to close down all toilets in the building except the ones on level 1; there's always a queue ten minutes long. Don't bother with it at all.

An interesting building. The QVB was refurbished some years ago into a place for overpriced boutique stores to sell their wares to overpaid city people. Which is fair enough given everyone is in on the secret!Effectively the attraction here isn't so much the pretty clothes and name brand tsunami on display but the building itself, set as it is in the CBD right near Town Hall station it is highly likely that if you spend any time at all in Sydney you will walk by this place. The signature piece is the statue of Queen Victoria, the second most striking aspect of the building is its shape and size as it is effectively one long tunnel of consumerist excess. With multiple levels and some cafes that are as pretentious as the people sitting in them this is the sort of place whose contents you'll either love or loathe but one this is for sure the long edifice is in contrast to much of what is around it.A place to at least wander through if only to window shop.

WOW. This is a beautiful iconic building - great shopping, very very busy food courts. Heaps so to see and do. Very helpful staff in all the shops. Trains, bus and fairies close at hand. This is a must to visit when in Sydney, we will be back when next visit.

Gorgeous. I have arched this beautiful lady be transformed from do and dowdy to spectacular . I just love browsing the amazing shops and having in one of its many tea rooms. But my favourite activity is going to the top floor, in the old fashioned lifts and looking over the whole building and the stunning lead light windows.This is just gorgeous! Love it, love it, love it!

Worth visiting, even for non-shopper. I am never a shopper when I go oversea trip. I'd rather spend my time wandering in the parks. However, I must admit, Queen Victoria Building is a place that worth visiting, even if you don't plan to do any shopping. This building is elegant, stylish, and nostalgic. Even the toilet is spotless :)

Beautifully restored old building full of upmarket shops. The Queen Victoria building is a Beautifully restored old building full of upmarket shops. It's definitely worth a look for visitors to Sydney

Good restaurants. I never tire of spending time here when in Sydney; especially Victoria's Basement (which may well be listed separately) The building can be easily recognised by the large statue of Queen Victoria near the entrance. There is also a statue of a small talking dog - and wishing well. From there, you can also walk quite a distance underground where there are lots of nice cafes, shops etc. The inside of the building is stately with beautifully marbled floors - different in each section, old style elevators, stained glass windows and gracious archways. Every part of the building is spotless. There's lots of good restaurants to choose from but if you just want a quick snack to take away, head underground. The best viewing point for the chiming clock is on the top level, although there are lots of large advertising posters hanging from the ceiling so make sure you look for the right vantage point. This is a real step back in time to the era of style & elegance.

Elegant. A most amazing building that is stylish on the outside and improves when entered. Inside there are many magnificent features which include marbled floors, stained glass window, ornate clock, spiral staircase and the stylish tiered shopping area.

Beautiful building. It's a gorgeous shopping center to visit for the interior decorations.
However the shopping itself was underwhelming. We did not find shops which we were interested to browse.

amazing architecture. this is one of the most well planned architecture buildings in Sydney, and MUST be visited.
the place as a shopping center - don't count on it...

Wonderful old building. This building is beautiful, stained glass windows and tiled floors add to the ambience of the place. The shops are definitely 'top end' - great to just look through the windows of if you don't have the money for the items. Lovely coffee shops to enjoy. Bon Bon Chocolate shop, wonderful model shop, something for everyone to enjoy. We visited it twice in our stay.

Queen Victoria Building. This elegant building is worth a visit, if only to see the "clock" which sounds on the hour with its own show. Forget shopping or eating here. The shops are not what one would expect to see in a historic building such as this. They are mediocre at best. They're on par with the restaurants - also mediocre. I guess that they're playing to tourists, thinking that, no matter what they sell or what they serve, it's a "one shot deal." We'll never see them again. We had lunch in the Chinese restaurant on the second level (didn't bother to take the name as it was awful) - how can they do such a bad dim sum? But do see the building!

Worth the visit. Restored 19th century building in the heart of Sydney. I recall visiting this site in the 70's, prior to restoration, and even then it was a wonder, especially viewing the centre clock pieces. Post modernisation now provides and abundance of restaurants and shops, and is a very busy site on weekends. Worth the visit although a little expensive.
Beautiful. QVB has beautiful building and interior. Just like the other shopping center, but the design is really beautiful.

Lots of shopping. Real shopping spree here. Like the way it interconnects with the westfeild shopping mall. New victorias secrets recently opened. The clocks were cool and the old architecture was great. Some boutique and fashion branded stores. We were there over easter and there were massive sales. The outside of this old building nestled amoungst new is refreshing

The clock. The QVB is a shopping centre like many others. Didn't see anything worth reporting except the clock. On the hour it uses puppets to tell a story which is very interesting including an execution

lovely shop's for window shopping or more. Lovely place for window shopping or more , cheaper shops in the basement more affordable prices well worth A browser especially if you can escape without your man . I left mine in the pub n found him hour's later .
Beautiful!!!. If you're visiting Sydney, I would highly recommend! Love the interior of this place. You'll find almost everything you'll need here. Free wifi on 1-3rd floors too!

Beautiful building. What a beautiful old building, worth to have a walk through it.
Didn't have a chance to look at all the shops.

A bit of history in the middle of the city. Fabulous building with lots of historical features. Love the centrepiece clock! Some great boutique shops and good (albeit overpriced) cafes and restaurants. Something to do on a rainy day.

Nice to pay a visit if have extra time. The outlook of QVB is outstanding but as other travelers may comment things are too expensive. I personally felt that the interior is quite romantic with the old style design and light is a bit dim compared to other arcade. It is located just opposite the Sydney Town Hall and is in the heart of the CBD. There are lot of boutique and small cafe inside the arcade which is good to spend a afternoon tea there.

Boutique Type Shopping. Too expensive for this pensioner to shop at but well worth a look from the visually stimulating aspect. There are two very unusual clocks hanging in the central gallery between the floors but it's hard to get a decent photo of them without including the huge, ugly banners advertising I know not what. The curved staircases with huge stained glass windows on outer walls are very eye-catching, as is the crystal chandalier in the Chinese Restaurant on the top floor, visible through an archway while standing at the top of one of the escalators. And I have to say, the conveniences are the fanciest I have seen for many a year, though they are in need of a bit of TLC. The long granite vanity you encounter when you first enter is impressive, but from there on it's all downhill, so much so that one of the cubicle doors is so ill fitting that daylight (and other things) can be seen through the gap!

Better on the outside. The QVB looks amazing from the outside, but when you go inside you realise that it is just the same as any Old World arcade. It is located in the middle of the CBD under the shadow of the Sydney Tower, and you find lots of small cafes and shops in the QVB. Additionally, it is a focal point of the area, and used as a meeting place, both underground and above ground by the roads. You can see many businessmen and tourists standing near the QVB eating their sandwiches and talking on their phones. When you are in the CBD part of Sydney then a 15 minute stroll around the arcade inside QVB is a must, just to take in the history of it all. However, it is not a true tourist attraction, so don't plan your day around it.

A must to visit while in Sydney. Even if you are not shopping it is well worth a walk through this building. Mainly upmarket shopping, but inside and out this building is a sight to see. Especially the roof area.
Good old charming building. Still drawing in the crowd; mostly for coffee and cakes at its entrance and inside cafes. Good access walk way to Westfield shopping centre

Architectural Gem in the heart of Sydney. Great place for high-end shopping and nice coffee shops, but the real draw for my family and me was the impressive architecture. From the vaulted ceilings to the mosaic floors, curved iron stairs to the intricate clocks (best seen from 3d level), this is a place to see and appreciate a fine building which has been well restored. Nice antique prints on the third floor, as well as higher-end Australian souvenirs. My boys enjoyed the 2-level hobby store. We ate lunch at the Viennese Coffee shop and the food and servive were good.
Beautiful!. Not only is this building beautiful but it has some great shops in it as well. We went everyday as it was close to our hotel, had some great cafes, and was interconnected to other malls.
Stunning. The building is amazing. Very pretty and well cared for. We had the most delicious tea too. It is well worth the visit.
An up-market shoppers heaven!. Lovely building with long arcade with skylight over. A couple of levels. Mostly well known high-end shops, very expensive. Some busy cafes.

Try visiting when it's quieter. If you can get there early morning you get a chance to see the building without all the workers and shoppers - you do see more. We love looking at the 2 massive clocks, and on this visit discovered the Victoria Cross memorial in the centre of the building; well worth a look. And having the chance to look closely at the floors, stained glass windows and the dome ceiling without worrying about people all around was fun too. That said, it's a vibrant place at any time of day, plenty of cafes, specialty shops etc to keep you interested.

Lovely building. Huge building, developed in recent years to retain old world appearance. Sits between modern high rise. Plenty of shops inside to peruse, mostly higher end tho. A very pleasant way to spend an afternoon
Pricy stuff, but a beautiful building.. This is probably the Ritz of shops in Sydney. Coach was probably the lowest end shop in here, and the architecture is breath taking.

Shopping & Food!. A really impressive restoration of a wonderful building! Overseas visitors were really amazed to see such a great & Victorian shopping centre! The shops were expensive but the cafes were excellent & good value!

So many temptations!. The Queen Victoria Building is a restored classic, next to Town Hall Station in heart of Sydney. With several stories upstairs plus underground shops, a person can spend the day there enjoying the architecture, the shops, & the dining. Coffee and pastry shops abound, jewelry, shoes, clothes...all fun & sparkly. Gorgeous old building. A great place to have a coffee or glass of wine & people-watch all day long. Even if you don't want to shop, see the building for its architectural & historical merits.

A beautiful old heritage building. QVB is a lovely old building with stained glass windows and a mosaic tile floor. Watch the clock chiming and display on the hour. Best seen from higher floors. Many restaurants and eateries here along with retail shops. The ground floor leads through to Town Hall railway station on one end and to Sydney Central shopping arcade at the other.

beautiful. what a beautiful building! amazing clock in the middle, you have to look at the details of everything to really appreciate the beauty of this place. beautiful shops too but on the pricy side. really nice coffee shops. I loved it! a must do in sydney!

Wonderfully restored building. Although the shops are mainly those that sell higher value items, the building is well worth a visit for the architecture and the clock alone. Worth stopping at the "top of the hour" for the clock chimes.
Great Place to Shop and Eat. Love QVB, it has a lot of shopping and so many choices too, the food outlets are excellent for coffee or lunch or both. Starbucks is in the building also which is great.
Beautiful structure.... Its a beautiful structure inside out. Quite a Good number of shops which have a very good collection of items.
Lovely Building. Lovely building, five years ago went here for high tea and wanted to return because it was such a lovely venue.

a Beautiful Old Building. This is a converted building. now made up of some nice and some boutique shops, try the chocolate shop, Hughes, a free sample, then be prepared to part with some cash
Seriously nice chocolate¬

Shopping and small food stops. basically youre just passing through or shopping at the very many expensive stores in the QVB or stopping at a fairly expensive pitstop cafe in the middle of the walkway.

History is beautiful. Just beautiful,so old and glorious very stunning,selections of different shops and food court was ok
Great to go at Xmas as they have an Exquite Christmas Tree
Great brands

Gorgeous site with clock show on the hour. And great tea or coffee too!
Fresh off an overnight flight, but unable to get in our room, we wandered down George Street. So glad we did. Found I'M Free tour and this shopping area, for a well needed caffeinated drink.
Time it well for there are two clocks, and a show they put on at the hour!

What a beautiful place to shop. I spent an hour just walking through the Queen Victoria Building looking at all the small amazing details. The floors to the ceiling are beautiful as well as the two beautifully crafted clocks full of amazing detail. I just loved walking through this building and had I not eaten lunch before I would have stopped and ate there.

Stunning Renovation on this Building. This building is one of the most beautiful shopping centers in the world, just stunning. make sure to look up at the ceiling in the center and at all the beautiful tile and iron work throughout. Also make sure to stop by Haighs chocolates, I dare you to leave without buying something delicious.

Good but I found it amusing how much people pay for tea and cake. Very nice (and very delicious) but not really good value for money if that is what you are after. We went for a special occasion but I still found it overpriced, possibly because high tea is a more common and therefore a cheaper activity in the UK . It amused me greatly how many people pay such a ridiculous amount for what is essentially tea, cake and sandwiches.I must say we had the cocktail package and the cocktails were very nice, as was the tea, the cakes and everything in between. The setting was very grand but the illusion broken by the less glamerous toilets (which were situated down a long corridor). Overall it was a lovely experience and made some lovely photos but was terribly overpriced despite it being a special occasion.
Amazing shopping . From the cafés to all the shops this building is certainly one of my favourite places to shop, being in the heart of Sydney and so close to everything else. Is a must!

A bit of everything. From jeweleries to cafes to clothes there is a little bit of everything there. The architecture of the building is beautiful in an old style.
Pay attention to the big clocks in the corridors, they are beautiful.

A blast from the past. Loved this building , beats all the modern shopping malls , classy
and sophisticated . Stained glass windows and two magnificent clocks that are suspended from the ceiling , beautifully tiled floors , everything spotlessly clean . The strand just a bit further up George street is equally as beautiful but on a smaller scale
A lovely spot. The QVB has lots of very good shops, very good coffee (in the centre atrium) and free wi-fi. A great place to 'people watch' as you have your morning coffee

Revived. It took a lot of getting used to what had been done to this building. It's days of glory have been modernised and is that a good thing? In a city like Sydney, I guess so. Sadly, nothing was affordable inside other than taking photos. Worth a visit on your way to Central station. Catch a movie along the way!

Her Majesty Queen Victoria. An amazing historical building beautifully restored and many specialty shops for the cashed up traveller with top quality goods of all varieties. Two levels and one can gaze down from the second floor and note the beautiful marble floor, ornate lights and wrought iron ballistrades. As you leave the building or enter it, depending from which side you come, a magnificent statue of the Queen greats you in all its glory!
Impressive red stone shopping mall. Very nice architectureLovely clocks on ceiling Shops are mid rangeCentral on George streetLovely statue of queen Victoria outside that they lifted from Ireland
Like being in England. This really is an excellent place to spend a few hours.Plenty of interesting shops.It seems to specialise in old fashioned high tea and the cakes look delicious

Still a very awesome building from any angle. Grand old lady of style and interesting selection of shops. The architecture is impressive. The rent must be very high here as the prices of retail goods is high end $.

A stunning rennovation. The QVB is full of quite expensive high-end shops in the heart of Sydney and, as prime real estate, so it should be. While we didn't go there to shop, the beauty of the architecture, the high quality of the stained glass windows and the most amazing clock made the visit a highlight. HIghly recommended

Queen Victoria Building. Probably our favourite place in Sydney...we went three days in a row! The architecture alone was breathtaking from windows to stairwells to elevators. The shops are beautiful and a great place to have afternoon tea called The Palace on the third floor.

Gorgeous. So glad we were able to visit the QV building and shop in style! We ended up staying after many shops closed -- as the crowds disappeared it was easier to see the building's elegant architecture and gorgeous windows.

Shoppers paradise. An amazing mall inside a stunning building. The architecture of this building is amazing, truly the Victorian stonemasons were masters of their craft.
Guys go to the pub and leave the women to shop but cancel the credit card first.

A great place to browse. We recently spent a night in the city and browsed the QVB as part of our stay. The whole place is an experience! but the shops on the third floor, including the Met Shop, Mont Blanc, and of course HobbyCo are just great to browse and be tempted and when you get tired there are coffee shops and eateries on every floor.

Beautiful arcade and good for window shopping. See the clock chime on the hour and watch the events unfold on the rotating lower part of the clock. You can look at the dog fountain outside and listen to it talk ( curious that it was given the voice of John Laws).

Beautiful Building. love love love this place. walked it with my partner, loved walking into all the little shops. lots of top designers and fashion forward shops. Must visit for shopaholics and history buffs

Lovely historical building. It is well worth a walk through this building to appreciate the architecture and the two large clocks. Unfortunately, the feature clock no longer does its "show" as of 2 years ago, which was a disappointment as I had seen it 10 years ago and was impressed. There are lots of lovely shops to browse through and I noted that prices in many were within reason. Worth a walk through. Check out Victoria's Basement for incredible deals on beautiful china and kitchen wares.

Not impressed. I recently had five days in which to see as much of Sydney as it was possible to pack in. During a quick visit on Wednesday I picked up a leaflet advertising a guided tour of the QVB on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays at 11.30am. The time had been hand-written in to amend the time originally printed of 1pm. At $15 for a 45 minute tour I thought this was on the high side but, as this is something I usually very much enjoy, I returned to the city the next day and timed it to present myself at Concierge fifteen minutes before the appointed time. Imagine my disappointment to be told these no longer run at 11.30 and I should return at 1.30 to take the tour? My schedule for the day did not allow for this, nor for my last three days which were already mapped out. There was no apology offered: in fact the whole issue was dealt with very nonchalantly. How long would it take to go through the leaflets on display an check the time was correct, especially as the time had been amended once already. How many other similar leaflets are already in people's hands?I have to say the QVB has remained remarkably unchanged since my first visit over twenty yeas ago. I commend their building maintenance programme, it is an effective one. Pity the same cannot be said for the upkeep of the Ladies restroom: half an hour later there was no soap at the wash station I used; this is obviously not checked regularly.i have rated this from a customer satisfaction viewpoint only. I did not shop or eat there.
Stunning Architecture. For architecture buffs, this is a great one to see. Although the stores inside are modern, the original style of the building has been preserved amazingly.

A beautiful old building.. There is a lot of good stores at the Queen Victoria building and it is worth visiting. There is a lovely tea room on the top floor that does amazing High Teas. Even if you don't like shopping it is worth visiting this place just to look at the stain glass windows and building itself.

SHOPPING SHOPPING SHOPPING. Love this old building. Variety of great stores for handbags, shoes and clothing and cafes for a latte, breakfast or lunch. Victorias Basement is worth a visit for homewares.

How lovely is this?. I didn't spend any money there. Not interested in shopping, I'm a man! But I took a whole load of photos, inside and out. The clock (inside) depicting scenes from Australian history is fantastic.

Spectacular Architecture and Stained Glass. It's probably a bit odd to say that a shopping mall is outstanding, but truly the QVB Building is for that. Several levels of shopping and restaurants with just about anything you could possibly want to purchase. However, the building itself is what is so outstanding. The architecture is distinctive and there are many beautiful stained glass windows. So take a peek at a bit of unique history. There are multiple escalators and/or elevators so the building is quite easy to get around. Just outside, don't forget to go to the fountain where Queen Victoria's "Scotty" Dog is. Push the button there and hear his story!
Wow Yourself By Seeing This Place!. They made this incredible building into a Shopping Mall well worth seeing because the architecture is memorable, historic and unique!

Two reasons why I frequent QVB.. 1. There is an awesome hobby store located at the top floor. It's called Hobbyco. That's where I purchase many of my aircraft models. They have one huge collection over there. Rare ones included!2. One of my favourite cafes is Jet Cafe. Located at the ground floor. I would go there for coffee and beer on a fairly regular basis.

Magnificent building.. Loved the honey coloured stone and the absolutely huge size of the place. Some very exclusive shopping inside. Thankfully the wife didn't find anything she liked and we moved on. Proved to be only a temporary reprieve. Loved shopping here just for the grandeur and history and lovely decor.
lovely building. lots of shops to visit. nice building plus good places to have a coffee. Love the atmosphere . there are a good selection of quirky shops.
fascinating place. interesting architecture and great shops/boutiques with so many underground connections to other malls - quite amazing

Deserves at least a walk-through. Amazing building with magnificent interiors. Lots of top brand stores for those who like to shop. Even if you are not looking to buy anything, this building at least deserves a walk through.
Different city mall.... Inner city mall, has a selection of shops, great architecture. Is connected to The Galleries Victoria, Westfield Sydney, just got down to the basement level.
Like stepping back in time.... Another large shopping complex in the heart of Sydney. All in a period designed building. A must see if you have some time.

shopping mall , a bit more sophisticated. historic buidling - 3 stories up with a choice of international shops, some nice cafes, a kids floor, antiques and jewels - verrrrry nice to stroll around. lower level is packed with more shops, more convenient and some easy food stores and leading to the public transports.

Always chaotic and busy. I've given up going there. It's chaotic, busy and the shops are just so so. Cafes are expensive and the shops are mostly international brands that you find everywhere. The building has some architectural merit but give the shops and cafes a miss. Go elsewhere.

Excellent !!. Evenif you are not a shopping fan, you must visist thus place.Excellently managed and decorated and literally takes you back to the era of queen Victoria. One of the few costliest shops of sydney you can find here. Price increases as you go more up on the floors.We visited on xmas time and the x'mas tree there was the best i ever seen in my life ! Not only that it was huge but it was such a beautifully and artistically decorated....it was Amazing.
Classic. A beautiful classic building with a wonderful array of shops. Very close to carry lots of shopping !
splendid. awesome building history & architecture at it most superb, love all different shops love the staircases & ornate glassware, what about the tree!!
QVB. Great shopping, wonderful cafes and a very cosmopolitan feel in the heart of Sydney town. A must for all to experience great shops of a high quality.

Shoppers Paradise. We bumbled into the QVB shopping area. Holy cow that place is amazing. If you want to shop this is the place. Get a map because this area is deceptively huge. If you can't find it there, they don't have it in AUS.

Queen Vic Building - a place of charm and style. My hotel was so close to the Queen Vic Building it would have been almost criminal not to visit. No concerns about that. If one wants a variety of fashion, it’s here. Great coffee, it’s here and there’s choice – restaurants, coffee shops, takeaway bars if you’ve ventured into the subway. There are some that you can easily gauge their popularity by the number of people at the establishment. Try one of those. There’s a host of other shopping possibilities, too. If you decide to visit, allow yourself time. You can’t visit the building and do it justice in a short visit. I love the atmosphere and charm of this heritage listed building.My favourite, Victoria’s Secret, in the basement where one can acquire quality branded housewares at well below retail price. Pick your time pack your patience, too, because it could be a crush: the basement which sells mainly quality brands is very popular and I regularly return on each visit to Sydney. All I need is more baggage weight to convey the articles. How fortunate are the Sydneysiders in this regard.The building is close to Town Hall station and endless buses go past. While you’re visiting the building, be sure to travel in the lifts (an experience in itself) to the upper level to view the royal clock. It’s a great visit to the past, colourful and very interesting, and while I could describe it in detail, I simply suggest you go yourself. Try to be there on the hour to see a complete performance by the clock. Be early for the viewing so you obtain a spot for photographs. It’s a popular sight to put on the list of things to do.Oh, yes, and don’t forget your credit card. A coffee may satisfy you during a visit but I would be surprised if you weren’t tempted to buy something else during a visit to the Queen Vic. Building because, while it’s not a $2 shop, not everything here is exorbitantly priced.

Wow, what a lovely building. "Bumped" into the Queen Victoria Building by accident - suddenly found ourselves in the amazing shopping centre with lovely architecture. Love the way the original building has been kept and maintained.

Beautiful building. Went in to look at the lights on Christmas Eve and loved the way QVB had dressed up the inside of the building with a huge tree and lots of lights. Also went in to shop during the day and loved the fashion stores, spent a bit more than I should have!

Nice old building. If you are staying longer than 3 days, I would recommend this old building. It is kept in great condition. However there is not much to see beyond the shops and I wouldn't recommend coming here if you are in a rush.

Shopping and then some. The QVB is a an excellent use of a historic building. Slated for demo in the 1970s and 1980s, the QVB was revitilized into a shopping mecca. Lots of cute, non-chain stores. Check out the basement for cheap eats on the go!

Classy mall. Gorgeous shopping arcade saved from the wrecking ball not so long ago. Many levels with all kinds of shops but make sure to go to the top level at the top of any hour to watch the English history clock chime through it tableaux of British history including the signing of the Magna Carta and the beheading of Charles I. Be sure to see Queen Victoria's talking dog at the Town Hall entrance.
wonderful. ideal for half an hour to half a day to experience this wonderful building, the shops are ok but the cafes are good and not expensive.
